PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Government's attack upon the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has cast grave doubts over the future viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide much-needed service to the community, including particularly those in rural areas;
The proposed changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will further jeopardise the viability of pharmacists;
The latest decision to slash PBS payments to pharmacists by an average $1.05 per script is simply unacceptable and will force the closure of many pharmacies.

Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure adequate remuneration levels for pharmacists, so that they may be able to provide a high quality health care service which is the right of every citizen of Australia.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, the undersigned, having great concern that Canberra is now the ``Porn Capital'' of Australia and because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation, call upon the Federal Government to introduce immediate legislation in support of existing State legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over the importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video cassettes, particularly in the ACT, with the open sale and/or hire of only `G', `PG' and `M' rated video cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale or hire of `R' rated video cassettes, so that `R' rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated or ``NVE'' rated video cassettes, which would allow the legal sale and hire of hard core pornographic videos for viewing in the homes of our nation, which would endanger our children; and
2. To give whole-hearted support to Senator Walter's Private Member's Bill to implement the recommendations of the Select Committee on Videos; and

3. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of video tapes/discs, which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and especially mailing by Australia Post, so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film, which exploits or degrades women as sex objects, or which contain child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex or violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc., or which promotes homosexuality or lesbianism.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will

(1) prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as real estate agents, mortgage underwriters, insurance companies, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment
(2) add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable businesses to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:-
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Note, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The Members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War, the Australian Government approved an end of war list of gallantry medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an end of war list at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government, and thus approve an end of war list for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the end of War list, the case of Warrant Officer Kevin Conway, Australian Army Training Team Vietnam, be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arrest of Dr Jin Yeop Kim
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

We call for the Australian Government to protest in the strongest possible way to the Government of the Republic of Korea against the arrest and subsequent detention of Australian Missionary and Dentist, Dr Jin Yeop Kim; demanding his immediate release by the Korean authorities and his total exoneration of the charge of ``knowingly aiding a North Korean Agent.''
Your petitioners humbly pray that Senators call upon the Government to implement the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

``(2) Subject to subsection (3), a person is not qualified to be appointed as a Commissioner if he or she:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs reported to this Parliament some time ago in relation to the disqualification of members of the Federal Parliament. I now formally wish to move amendment No. 46 which is an amendment to insert a new clause after clause 36 at page 20 of the Bill. The new clause concerns disclosure of interests by commissioners. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (46) Page 20, after clause 36, insert the following new clause:
Disclosure of interests

``36a. (1) Each Commissioner shall make to the Minister a written disclosure of the [financial] interests of the Commissioner and the members of the Commissioner's immediate family equivalent to the disclosure of financial interests required to be made by officers of the Australian Public Service who are members of the Senior Executive Service.
``(2) A Commissioner shall make a disclosure under subsection (1) within one month after being appointed as a Commissioner.

I should say that it has been followed except when the acting commissioners appointed by the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, took office in May 1988. Up to that time the practice had been followed. This practice required a disclosure of interests by commissioners and the disclosure was in the form which is proposed in this amendment. If a commissioner has financial interests which may relate to the work being done by the Commission, then it is proper that the other commissioners know of those financial interests. This clause is drafted merely to try to make that clear and to put that provision into statutory form. I seek clarification from the Minister on that matter. I note that the circulated amendment has the word `financial' in subclause 1 in square brackets. I take it that that is there because there is some question as to whether it is desirable to have the word there. I would just like an indication or a bit of advice from the Minister as to whether he thinks it should be there. I think it probably should be there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's your amendment, though.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Committee that there is no need to move amendment No. 47 as we dealt with a replacement amendment a few moments ago. I now proceed to amendment No. 48. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (48) Page 21, subclause 38 (7), lines 3 to 7, leave out the subclause.

Amendment No. 48 seeks to leave out proposed subclause 7 of clause 38 which appears on page 21 of the Bill. The first thing to ask ourselves is why subclause 7 has been inserted in the Bill. The subclause proposes that a commissioner shall be taken to be guilty of misbehaviour-I quote from the subclause:

if he or she has voted in favour of, or knowingly participated in, a contravention of a lawful direction given by the Minister to the Commission, whether under section 12 or 73 or any other provision of this Act.

Clearly this subclause has been inserted to meet what the Government sees as the problems encountered by the Minister in early May 1988. That was the time the Minister actually issued a direction to the then commissioners. The then commissioners determined to test that direction by going to the Federal Court. They advised the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs-a committee on which Senator Coulter, Senator Boswell and I served-that had the Minister's direction been found to be lawful, they would have obeyed it. They were not certain that it was lawful for several good reasons. Firstly, no Minister had ever given such a direction. They thought it appropriate to test it and the Federal Court was the appropriate place to do this. To be fair, I recall that Senator McMullan asked whether they could guarantee that they would not have appealed had they lost in the Federal Court. The point remains that had the commissioners found they were facing a lawful direction they would have obeyed it.

This subclause is drawn in such a way that it would be enough to have voted in favour of a contravention of a lawful direction given by the Minister; that is to say, if one voted not to accept a direction from the Minister today, sent it to the court and three months later it was found to have been a lawful direction, it could be said that one had voted against it. The Minister wishes to intervene and I yield to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume and I had a brief private discussion on this subclause of clause 38. I indicate to Senator Baume and Senator Coulter that I agree entirely with Senator Baume's general proposition that if members of such a commission-I use his terms-found that they were contravening a lawful direction, they would change their behaviour and obey it. There is no question of that. The point is that they need to know. I propose that in clause 38 (7), line 4, before the word `voted' we insert the word `knowingly'. The clause would then read:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . knowingly voted in favour of, or knowingly participated in, a contravention of a lawful direction given by the Minister to the Commission. . .

Of course, that means that a person then has full knowledge that what he is doing is in opposition to a lawful direction. I think most members of this chamber would agree that the consequences indicate that it should flow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it will be necessary for me to seek leave to withdraw my amendment. I do not want to do that immediately. However, I want to thank the Minister. The Opposition has had that concern which the Minister has now corrected. The other concern is that the clause actually states, `The Minister shall terminate the appointment of that Commissioner' if certain things happen: he shall-I emphasize the word `shall'-be taken to have been guilty of misbehaviour and, if he is guilty of misbehaviour, he shall be dismissed, terminated. We still think that provision, as drafted, is fairly coercive. Some attention needs to be given to that provision as well.
—I don't think you are right.
—I yield to the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, after consulting the Commission, suspend a Commissioner from office because of misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister that the subclause which he has just referred to me has been amended during the course of this debate by a government amendment. Therefore, I need to know what was that Government amendment and what was the effect of it before I can actually evaluate what the Minister has told me.

—As I understand it, I think that amendment only permits the commissioner to show cause why he should not be suspended from the Commission. In other words, it is a further protection, a further element if you like, in the way in which the Minister's ability or capacity to suspend the commissioner is modified. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the Minister's explanation I seek leave to withdraw my circulated amendment No. (48). I do so on the basis of the assurance the Minister has given me that he will then move a government amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the discussion so far has been somewhat oblique. The real point is the time at which the action the Commissioner takes is judged to be lawful or unlawful. There is some uncertainty about whether a direction is lawful and that is the point Senator Baume raised initially. The lawfulness or otherwise of a direction could be subject to testing in the courts. So a commissioner may, in good faith, have voted or acted in a way which was contrary to a direction, believing that the direction of the Minister was unlawful. It really does swing on the word `knowingly', which the Minister is seeking to include. Does `knowingly' mean that the matter has been fully tested before the courts and in the light of that information being known to the commissioner, that that commissioner then votes or behaves in a certain way, or does it mean simply believing at the time that it was lawful that the commissioner votes or acts in a certain way subject to the matter being tested before the courts? My own view on this is that the clause clearly has to be there. The appropriateness of the action which the Minister will take will be judged in the light of any court challenges which may either precede or follow the voting or the action. In the light of that judgment it will be judged whether the direction was lawful or not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the whole point. As the passage is presently drafted there seems to be a clear contrast between knowingly participating in a contravention of a lawful direction and simply voting with or without the knowledge that one is contravening a lawful direction. The officer from Parliamentary Council who is here this morning indicates that by putting the word `knowingly' in front of `voted' one ensures that the consequences can only flow if the commissioner knew at the time of voting that he or she was contravening a lawful direction. It is on that basis that I ask the Committee to support my amendment to subclause 7. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 21, subclause 38 (7), line 4, before ``voted'' sub (7), insert ``knowingly''.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition thanks the Minister. There is just one other matter in relation to this clause to which I ask the Minister to direct his attention. In this clause, particularly subclauses 5, 6 and 7, there is no requirement for the Minister to report or justify his action to the Parliament. Under those three subclauses the Minister may terminate the appointment of a commissioner and the Parliament may not know. I ask the Minister whether he would be willing to have a few words added simply to require the Minister to inform the Parliament if he takes any action under these subclauses, because at present there is no such requirement. If that was acceptable to the Minister, it could be drafted while he is out of the chamber.
—That is acceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The next circulated amendment is No. 49 but we dealt with that earlier today. The one after that, amendment No. 50, has been dealt with, as has amendment No. 51. Amendment No. 51 became 51a. We now move to amendment No. 52.

—For the sake of propriety, and because I have to leave the chamber almost immediately, and although Senator Baume said we `dealt with' these amendments, perhaps I may ask whether we have formally recorded a vote in relation to those amendments. I gave an indication, but I do not--
—I sought leave to move all those amendments together earlier. They were taken in globo because they were all in the same form, and we actually determined them at that time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (52) Page 50, subclause 116 (2), lines 21 and 22, leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
(2) A disclosure under subsection (1) shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting and the member shall not:
(a) be present during any deliberation of the Regional Council with respect to that matter; or
(b) take part in any decision of the Regional Council with respect to that matter.''.

As subclause 2 exists, it simply says `a disclosure under subsection (1)'. This is a disclosure of the interests of any regional council, so that if a member of a regional council has a financial interest in any of the matters coming before the council, at least his or her fellow regional councillors should know that fact. The subclause, as drafted, merely says that disclosure shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. We have sought to leave out that subclause and insert another subclause, which says:
A disclosure under subsection (1) shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting and the members shall not:
(a) be present during any deliberation of the Regional Council with respect to that matter; or
(b) take part in any decision of the Regional Council in respect of that matter.

The effect of that would be that if I had a pecuniary interest, direct or indirect, in a matter to be considered or about to be considered by a regional council, I would then declare that interest, it would be recorded in the minutes of the meeting, and I would then, if this amendment was carried, withdraw from the meeting and not take part in any decision, because I should not take part while having a direct or indirect pecuniary interest.

I advise members of the Committee that I represent this Parliament on the council of the Australian National University (ANU). It is now public knowledge that at our last council meeting we had to discuss the question of amalgamation within the Australian Capital Territory, and one of the members of the ANU council raised with the Chancellor in advance the question of whether the Vice-Chancellor had a direct or indirect pecuniary interest. The reason for this was that, if we chose to amalgamate and there was a new amalgamated institution, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) had already indicated, our Vice-Chancellor would become the Vice-Chancellor of the new amalgamated institution. It was interesting that the Chancellor quite properly referred that matter to the university solicitor, who decided that the Vice-Chancellor had no direct or indirect pecuniary interest under the meaning of the Act but that the Deputy Vice-Chancellor did. At the ANU Council, that was recorded in the minutes, and when the matter came up for discussion the Deputy Vice-Chancellor then withdrew from the meeting and took no part in the discussion or the decision, as he was required to do. If there is a matter in which I have an interest and it is to be determined in a collegium such as a university council represents, then I should not take part in that decision.

Let us look at what might happen in a regional council. Regional councils should be in the business of making decisions about the allocation of resources. They are in the business of making decisions which will be in favour of one and against another. They will be making choices about using limited resources to meet very great demands. They will be in the business of saying yes to some and no to others. We know already that the voting system proposed is a proportional voting system. We can suspect that the largest identifiable group may well have the largest number of members on a regional council. What I want to avoid is that all the money goes to them. I want to make sure that decisions are at least taken on some reasonable basis. We are in a quandary, because if I say that no-one is able to speak on his or her own behalf, then who will speak for that person? On the other hand, if a person has a dominant voting position, that person can affect the distribution of resources, the preparation of the draft budgets, in an unreasonable way.

In reporting to the Parliament on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989, the Senate Legislative Scrutiny Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills looked at this matter. It discussed the clause that dealt with disclosure of interest. It said:

This clause is in similar terms to clause 101 in the previous Bill and requires a member of a Regional Council to disclose a direct or indirect pecuniary interest in a matter before the Council, and that interest is to be recorded in the Minutes of the Meeting.
The Scrutiny of Bills Committee went on to say:
This provision is compared with:
(1) Clause 36-where a member of the Commission-
this is a member of the Commission now as opposed to a member of a regional council-

is required to disclose any pecuniary interest which is duly recorded in the Minutes. Subclause 36 (2) provides that the Commissioner cannot be present, or take part in any decision relating to that matter.

I interpolate that we have already determined that should commissioners have a direct or indirect pecuniary interest, not only must that be recorded in the minutes but also the commissioners cannot be present and cannot vote. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee went on to say:
Subclause 159 (1) and (2) are similar provisions relating to disclosure by a Director of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Board.

The Committee has yet to get to that part of the Bill but we are aware that ahead of us lies the question of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation board. It has similar provisions. If there is a direct or indirect pecuniary interest it shall be recorded in the minutes, the person shall not be present and shall not vote. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee went on to say:

The Committee sought comment from the Minister on the reason for the difference between the disclosure of interest provisions for members of Regional Councils, compared to those imposed on a Commissioner or a Director of the Board.
Because we are trying to be fair here I will read the second paragraph of the Minister's response to that, which was in the following terms:

The reason for the difference relates primarily to the role and functions of regional councils. Regional councils will frequently deal with matters that will necessarily directly or indirectly affect the pecuniary interests of all the regional councillors. In such circumstances, a provision requiring councillors not to take part in decisions and decision-making would prevent the regional council from fulfilling its functions.

Then the Scrutiny of Bills Committee thanked the Minister and recommended nothing. I believe that we have to test the Minister's response. Unless the Minister's response is sustainable, I believe it is of no force. The Minister said:
Regional Councils will frequently deal with matters that will necessarily directly or indirectly affect the pecuniary interests of all the regional councillors.

It would have to be a very indirect interest to have that happen because, while it may be direct for some, it would be quite indirect for others. One might say that someone involved in a question of allocation of resources has a direct pecuniary interest in every vote. Only if one believed that the Opposition's amendment would make the operation of regional councils impossible-and that is not the intention of the Opposition-would one wish to oppose our amendments.

We believe that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's acceptance of the Minister's advice is not well based. The closer people are to the issues-that is, the issue which may be under discussion in a regional council: `Do we fund a new medical service in such and such a town?', for example-the greater will be the difficulties where people actually have a pecuniary interest and the more important it will be to separate people, to take out people who have a direct interest and ensure that they are not part of the decision and the vote. The option of remaining in the meeting with the agreement and consent of the other people there was not recommended for attention and the same principle should apply in regional councils. When I say it was not recommended for attention in the Commission, we are now looking at one level down from the Commission-at the regional councils. We believe that if it was good enough not to be recommended for the Commission the same principle should apply to the regional councils.

The amendment proposed by the Opposition would do three things: it would require that the matter be recorded in the minutes, that a person not be present in respect of that matter or that a person not take part in a decision. Unless someone can say that that would render the regional council unworkable, I believe there is no really good, sustainable argument against the amendment and I do not understand the proposition-I am open to be convinced-that it would render the regional councils unworkable. Unless that can be demonstrated, I think that this is another amendment which will not only help improve the legislation, but actually help the public perception about the fairness and propriety of the legislation and, to that extent, would actually help Aboriginal Australians in the job they have to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is another aspect which Senator Peter Baume has not mentioned; that is, when the regional councils deal with financial aspects, they will be dealing with budgets, and those budgets will be subject to amalgamation with the budgets of other regional councils, scrutiny by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and then, finally, an overview by the Minister. I would have thought that in relation to direct pecuniary interests the recording in the minutes of the interest of a particular person who has had a hand in the decision at the lowest level-that is, the regional council in relation to these draft budgets-so that that fact is known to both ATSIC and the Minister, would be sufficient for ATSIC or the Minister to consider, `Perhaps this has been influenced in some way which is not in the interests of the overall community which the regional council is attempting to help'.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that there is an element of truth in the argument which the Government is putting; that is, the small regional councils will represent sectional interests and probably many of them will have, in some sense or other, a pecuniary interest in the outcome of particular decisions. It may well make the councils unworkable if one were to deny access to the decision-making process of all the people who had an interest.

This is a matter of balance; it is a matter of sufficient revelation of the fact of a pecuniary interest combined with the other protections which are built in and which I think can be adequately implemented through the disclosure in the minutes procedure and that should be balanced against the desirability of having the whole regional council involved in the decision-making process. For those reasons the clause, as printed in the Bill, should be an adequate protection against those things which Senator Baume has drawn to our attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment that the Opposition has moved is quite reasonable. If a person has a monetary interest in a particular program, he should absent himself from the meeting. Where members of regional councils come together, it could well be that a member of a council is interested in developing a particular project-it could be a fishing boat, a farm, or anything else that one cares to mention. If that person attends the regional council meeting at the time that the project is being discussed and evaluated, I believe it will inhibit free and frank discussion. The regional councillors will be inhibited in making a statement in open debate. They may fear that there will be repercussions or that they will offend one of their colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is normal business practice on any council or board for a person who has a particular interest in a project, to absent himself from the room and leave the remaining people to debate the issue without his personal involvement. I do not see that what is being proposed now moves away from the way that business is run throughout Australia. I know that Senator Coulter would understand that if a person on a regional council wanted a particular project to go ahead his colleagues might not be able to debate the matter in an open way for fear that they might offend him. I do not see what the Opposition is moving here as being in any way different from the practice followed by any other board, council or institution in Australia. With this legislation, we are establishing a commission that will be massive in terms of money and influence. I urge the Australian Democrats to support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a bit surprised at Senator Boswell's response to what I was saying. He seems to be mistakenly implying that, like other boards of companies and other organisations, the regional councils will have hands-on day to day financial management. That will not be the case. The essential point is that most of the decisions they will be making will be of a more general, non-financial and philosophical nature. The financial part of their deliberations will be with respect to the draft annual budget, which will go through the processes that I have outlined. That is subject to significant safeguards, so I do not think that Senator Boswell is correct in drawing the sorts of parallels that he has. The question really is whether we want to exclude from these more general discussions people who might have pecuniary interests even though, in the specifically financial and budgetary deliberations, there will be oversight mechanisms through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and through the right of ministerial veto.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has been mentioned by Senator Coulter and Senator Peter Baume is that we need to get a fair and workable system in place. The approach that the Government has taken is the only workable and balanced way to go about this particular matter. What we are proposing is that if there is a potential conflict of interest there needs to be full disclosure.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume rightly referred to the Minister's response to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to the effect that there may often be situations where regional councillors have a pecuniary interest. They may, for example, be members of a particular corporation which has a claim on a budget which the council has to make a determination on. That could very well put them in a conflict of interest situation. It is also appropriate to look at another scenario. In a particular region a number of people may be on a whole range of bodies. Such people would need to prioritise their interests. To draw an analogy between the situations that we are trying to address with their peculiarly different characteristics and the university situation, as Senator Baume did, may be trying to apply a principle too rigidly in the sorts of circumstances we have to address.

The final point I want to make is one that I am glad Senator Coulter made. It is that regional councils will not handle money. They have decision making power in terms of prioritising and allocating funds, but there is a clear distinction between this situation and the one that Senator Boswell mentioned. In summary, it is very much the Government's clear submission that what we need to achieve and what we have achieved through a position of disclosure rather than the preclusion of people from a role on regional councils is the only workable way to go about this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must respond to a couple of points that have been made. First, it is simply not correct to say that the regional councils will have only the budget making decision where this question might arise. At this stage, I am the only person in the chamber who has actually been the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I know of the situation where money is allocated through a budgetary process and at a local level decisions then have to be made as to who will get the benefit of that money. I will give honourable senators an example. A housing association is given money to build four houses for which there are 15 applicants. I submit that the people who get the houses have a pecuniary interest in the matter. It is not simply a social interest but in many cases it is quite a pecuniary interest.

SPEECH.PARA: By just looking back a decade I can well remember-I think I have already mentioned it to the Committee-that in Kempsey violence went on between the members of the local group. Axes were put through the sides of motor cars because one group believed it was being unfairly treated in terms of the local allocation, well after the budget process was complete. Administrative matters which will involve advantage and disadvantage will be in the hands of regional councils when Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission becomes operational. They will represent a kind of pecuniary interest. That is the first thing.

The second thing I draw to honourable senators' attention is clause 36 of the present Bill which deals with the situation facing the commissioners of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It will become apparent from the words at the top of page 20 that the words we have proposed to add to clause 116 at page 50 are words which we have taken unchanged from an earlier clause of the same Bill. We have changed `Commissioner' to a `member of a Regional Council', but we have substantially taken the words unchanged from an earlier clause and moved them to clause 116 (1), so that the rules which apply to commissioners who have to declare or disclose an interest would apply to members of regional councils. I put it to the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) that I cannot believe that such a provision would, as it were, nobble the regional councils in carrying out their proper function, but if that is the view of the Government I ask the Minister whether there is not some middle reasonable road. I do so because I believe that a mere recording of a pecuniary interest in the minutes is not sufficient. It was not sufficient for the commissioners, and the Government's Bill includes the other provisions in relation to commissioners. I believe that something more is necessary. One way of handling it might be to ask our Parliamentary Counsel to look at some middle road. I cannot believe that a direct pecuniary interest would stop the operation of a regional council, and I find it very difficult to believe that an indirect pecuniary interest would stop it, but the Minister says that that could be the case.

The provision which we have proposed is consistent with that which is proposed for the Commission itself. It is appropriate that it be included for the regional councils and if, for technical reasons, the Government believes it goes a bit too far, then I would ask the Government to have our Parliamentary Counsel look at some other form of words which would achieve the kinds of safeguards which we believe are desirable, and which would provide a course of action consistent with that which will apply to commissioners in a way that would not place the position of regional councils in unreasonable jeopardy. I ask the Minister for some response to that proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that Senator Peter Baume's concern is one that is recognised and understood. While understanding the sort of problem he raises, the Government has responded to it in different ways, given different situations. Senator Baume rightly pointed to the rules governing the disclosure of interests by commissioners of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, when he referred to clause 36 (2) at the top of page 20 of the Bill. As I said earlier, and as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) said in his response to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, regional councils, however, are in a peculiarly different situation. We recognise the problem and we have tackled it in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the courtesy of his response, but we are still some distance apart. He is a Minister of the Crown. He will know that if a commission or a Minister were faced with the fact that at the local regional council level a group was unable to attract support for a project it is very unlikely that the Minister or the commission would seek to overturn that. The provision to which the Minister directed me merely provides that the regional council may be asked to re-examine its budget in specified ways.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has proposed the addition of two subclauses, (a) and (b). I indicate that we feel particularly strongly that no-one with a direct or indirect pecuniary interest should take part in a decision. If I were forced to say which of those two was the more important, I would say (b). People should simply not take part in a decision if they stand to gain from it. I cannot understand why the Committee would want to vote against that part of the amendment. We have suggested in option (a) that they should not even be present. I am willing to say that it might be the view of the Committee that perhaps people should be present, but we do not think they should take any part in the decision.

I have been close to the administration of these matters and I know what will happen. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Heaven preserve this Parliament and the people of Australia from academics and lawyers. I have an academic sitting beside me and the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who is in the chamber, is a lawyer. I can understand Senator Peter Baume's anguish over this clause because he has been Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and has been faced with the stark reality of Aboriginal corporate management in the field. When the white man arrived in Australia the Aboriginals did not have a cash mentality, let alone a cash economy. It has been only in recent decades that they have started to get a smattering of it. Part Aborigines, of course, are a bit further down the track towards a cash mentality and economy and moving to handle corporate affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to the administration of Aboriginal corporate affairs, there needs to be a supervisory role for the Government with regard to Aboriginal corporate management in the field. Senator Baume has described how it has led to violence in the past. Even now Aborigines do not distinguish between pecuniary interests, practical interests, and property interests, but they do understand that they can use corporate machinery to advantage one person and not another. They have practised this sort of thing. A long learning process will be involved.

The Minister and Senator Coulter may think that they are helping Aborigines by giving them greater licence to operate in this area, but Aborigines should learn that they have to declare pecuniary interests. If they have a pecuniary interest, or if it involves their own people-the skin debate, as it is referred to-they should learn not only to not take part in the debate-Senator Baume is proposing that they not take part in it-but also not to vote on the matter. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to direct the Committee's attention for a moment to clause 118. Clause 118 concerns persons taken to have resigned from regional councils in certain circumstances. I observe that, under clause 116 as it is drafted, the clause with which we have been dealing and which involves the disclosure of pecuniary interests, there is no sanction written in to discipline a councillor who fails to declare a pecuniary interest. SPEECH.PARA: . . . as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to the member's knowledge, disclose the nature of the interest at a meeting of the Regional Council.

That is clear enough. The question we then ask is: What happens if that regional councillor fails to undertake that procedure? SPEECH.PARA: (56) Pages 85 and 86, clause 222, lines 36 (page 85) to line 6 (page 86), leave out the clause.

This amendment has been circulated in the name of the Opposition. It relates to page 85 of the Bill and to clause 222. The Committee will recall that some time ago we dealt in group 3 with the Opposition's proposal to amend clause 221 of the Bill. The argument in this case is not really very different. The Opposition's proposal is that the clause be left out. The amendment actually proposes that. Clause 222 did not appear in the 1988 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill which appeared before the Parliament. The effect of the clause will be to enable the Minister to delegate his powers-I suggest that honourable senators look at the words-either to the Department or to an officer of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

This clause concerns the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act. It is proposed that the Minister could delegate his powers under that Act either to the Department or to an officer of ATSIC. Now this raises an issue which goes to the heart of the question. Who administers Aboriginal portfolio legislation under the new ATSIC proposal? This question was dealt with by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs in paragraphs 2.9 to 2.22 of its report. I will just refer honourable senators to that section as it is the one which deals with ministerial advice. It drew to the attention of the Senate in the agreed majority report the very great difficulty that existed for the Minister in receiving advice from a department or from a statutory commission. The Senate Select Committee recommended:
. . . a separate office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained within Employment, Education and Training portfolio . . . responsible for advising the Minister-
I want to emphasise the next words-
on all matters relevant to the portfolio-
I want to emphasise the next words-
including the administration of legislation and the exercise of delegations . . .

That is what Senator Boswell, Senator Coulter and I recommended to the Senate just a few short months ago. We chose our words carefully-that is at paragraph 2.22-in that Senate Select Committee report. We recommended that there be a departmental presence to advise the Minister on all matters relevant to the portfolio, including the administration of legislation and the exercise of delegation. But what the Government has proposed with this Bill is the amendment of most portfolio legislation to allow for a share-up of delegations between ATSIC and the Department. If we look at part 6 and division 5 we find that clause 222 refers to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, clause 224 to the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act, clause 225 to the Aboriginal Land (Lake Condah and Framlingham Forest) Act, and clause 226-a very important and quite sensitive clause-to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

The Senate Select Committee believes that the Minister should receive advice and retain his delegations. He should not pass them on to a statutory authority. We will reach a position where statutory authorities will deal with State and Territory governments saying that they have the carriage or authority under certain State legislation. It is an extremely provocative provision. Who will administer various parts of various Acts? Some bits will be administered by the Department and some bits will be administered by ATSIC. It is not an academic question. An officer working in ATSIC, or whatever office is created to advise the Minister, as required under the Constitution, will have to find out whether he or she has delegated authority or whether it belongs in the other place. We do not believe that the Government has paid any significant attention to the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee, to which at least three of us in this chamber were parties.

The Bill proposes that ATSIC will administer all these pieces of legislation under the delegation of the Minister. We believe that that was always the Government's intention. That is not what the Senate Select Committee recommended unanimously. Technically, the Minister administers legislation, but he has to have a department, staff or someone to perform the multitude of tasks which that legislation requires of him to make all the decisions contemplated by the legislation he administers. The constitutional propriety that has grown up over almost a century is that a Minister's department assumes the role of advising and assisting the Minister and accepting delegations. That is reflected in the Administrative Arrangements Order.

In the original ATSIC proposal there was to be a vacuum, because originally it was proposed that there be no department. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the transcript of evidence before the Senate Select Committee, particularly pages 223 to 229 and 235. That evidence established quite clearly that it was intended that ATSIC would administer all Aboriginal portfolio legislation, including the ATSIC Act. That was what the Committee was told by the officials who were preparing the ATSIC proposal.

The Committee came down with a recommendation which drew attention to the constitutional requirements and the practicalities. The Government's only reaction to the Senate Select Committee's recommendation was set out in the Minister's `The Way Ahead' statement of 11 April 1989 which appears at page 1336 of the Weekly Hansard of the other place. The statement reads:

With regard to the first recommendation of the Senate Select Committee that a separate Office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained within the Employment, Education and Training portfolio, I should point out that the ATSIC Bill does not restrict the advice available to the Minister to that provided by ATSIC. Indeed, it was always envisaged, under the ATSIC proposal, that there could be circumstances where the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and also the portfolio Minister, might occasionally require separate departmental advice on issues concerning ATSIC, and that this advice would come from the portfolio Department.

I emphasise `might occasionally require separate departmental advice'. That is not what the Senate Select Committee recommended. This situation is unprecedented in Commonwealth legislative dispositions. I will draw on some examples. Should an elected social security commission, chosen from a pensioner constituency, administer all pension laws? Should a veterans' commission, drawn from returned service men and women around Australia, administer all veterans' legislation? Should farmers elect some of their members to run the Department of Primary Industries and Energy? I am not talking about a statutory marketing authority: I am talking about the Department. A department of state is a constitutional entity which exists for a purpose. What is proposed here is quite unprecedented. The Minister wrote to his colleagues the State Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs on 5 January 1989 in the following terms:
10. Ministerial Responsibility.

A number of submissions to the Senate Select Committee have argued that it is inappropriate that Commission staff should advise the Minister responsible for ATSIC on the administration of legislation. It was argued that it was an established principle that Ministers take advice from their Department, and that the proposed arrangements under ATSIC breached that principle. It was further alleged that this situation would lead to a situation where the administration of legislation such as the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 could adversely impact on mining and pastoral interests.
The Minister's letter continues:
11. These arguments point to a fundamental misunderstanding of the Westminster principles of Ministerial responsibility.
This is the Minister's argument and I want to present it to be fair:

In all cases, it is the Minister who administers legislation. The Australian Constitution requires that Ministers be appointed to administer a Department; thus this source of advice is not ruled out by the ATSIC legislation. Nevertheless, there is no principle which requires the Minister to take the advice of the Department or, for that matter, the advice of the Commission-it is the Minister who is responsible, and who is accountable to Parliament for the administration of legislation. Moreover, ATSIC staff will be engaged under the Public Service Act, and will be expected to perform in a professional manner consistent with the norms of the Australian Public Service.

The allegation of a so-called `fundamental misunderstanding' is rubbish. Of course the Minister is responsible. We have never suggested otherwise. He can be advised from anywhere, but it is also the case that every Minister has a department. It is the department, not statutory authorities, that advises the Minister on the administration of the statutory authority's legislation. Of course, statutory authorities may have their own legislation, but there is still a department to advise the Minister about a statutory authority.

The Minister's reference to the Constitution is astounding. Section 64 of the Constitution states that Ministers are appointed to administer departments. Therefore, Ministers without portfolios are unconstitutional. But Ministers are appointed to administer departments. So the Westminster system has a Minister to administer legislation, a department to advise the Minister and statutory authorities which are able to do whatever it is the parliament has said they can do in whatever relationship with the Minister for which the statute provides.

I do not deny that, in a sense, we are entering uncharted waters. Nevertheless, I believe it is an arrangement which is now understood amongst the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I believe that, if the very essence of this ATSIC proposal is gutted at this stage in the way suggested by Senator Peter Baume's amendment and the two following, one would really be going back on the whole enterprise that the Government is engaged in. Therefore, I think it would really negate the second reading in-principle endorsement of ATSIC that has been given by this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the conclusion of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) is correct. At this stage, before I advance any other rebuttal, could the Minister explain to us, with regard to the piece of legislation we are talking about-I do not have a copy of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act with me-what this extra delegation might mean? What are some of the powers that are conferred on the Minister?

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the administration of Aboriginal affairs under the Constitution is a conjoint function of both the Commonwealth and the States. The 1967 referendum provided that what had been a State responsibility became a shared responsibility between the Commonwealth and the States. It is proper that the State Minister be involved. For reasons which I have set out already, it is proper in terms of our functioning as a Westminster parliament that the department for which the Minister is responsible be involved. I want to know, so I can attempt to understand this, exactly the kinds of powers and functions which might be delegated under this Act. For example, do they go to dealing and making decisions with the States? Do they involve giving any directions which might bind the States or other areas? What kind of orders might be involved? Only when we understand this can we understand the extent of what a delegation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission might mean for day to day administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are digging through our files to try to find whether we have a copy of the Act with the relevant provisions. I certainly cannot provide them off-the-cuff at the moment.

—The Minister has made a number of assertions which I cannot test until I have that information. I make one other comment: it is one thing for the Minister to claim that, because of the way in which the Bill is written, it is constitutional in the sense that the High Court would uphold its validity if it is challenged. That is one way of looking at it. I was arguing another matter. I was arguing whether it was proper-in the sense of constitutional propriety-to go down this track. The reason I offered the Minister that particular advising from the Attorney-General's Department is that it is relevant to the second point I am making-the question of the constitutional propriety of a course of action which would seek to make these various delegations not to a State Minister who actually has constitutional responsibility for Aboriginal affairs, not to an officer of the Department, which is the department of state properly appointed to advise the Minister, but to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, which is a statutory authority created within the portfolio and created under unique conditions within a unique structure. I ask the Minister to give us some idea of what kind of powers might be delegated under this proposed clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When one looks, as I am doing very briefly, at the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act 1984, one finds that section 31 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, either generally or as otherwise provided in the instrument of delegation, by writing signed by him, delegate to a person all or any of his powers and functions under this Act . . .

There are then major exceptions. They are section 9, which deals with emergency declarations in relation to areas, and section 10, which deals with other declarations in relation to areas. I think Senator Peter Baume will be conversant with and will remember these. This is where Aboriginal groups seek the preservation of a particular area from injury or desecration because it is significant and under threat of injury or desecration, according to their fears.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you read the functions clause?

—There is not a functions clause. Let me just finish the point I am making. The major powers of the Minister in sections 9 and 10 cannot be delegated. Section 12 is the same. Those declarations in relation to objects cannot be delegated. In subsection 13 (2) and section 26 the powers are conferred for the making of declarations in relation to an area, object or objects. Section 26 deals with the application of the Minister to the Federal Court of Australia for an injunction in relation to certain matters. Apart from those matters it appears that the Minister may delegate as provided in the regulations or declaration. Section 17 of the Heritage Act says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may, by instrument in writing, designate persons to be authorised officers for the purposes of this Division.

Quite clearly proposed clause 222 would enable that power to be delegated to the chief executive officer or a member of the staff of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Section 18 of the Heritage Act deals with emergency declarations in relation to areas or objects. My advice is that that is another example of a power that could be delegated to the chief executive officer or a member of the staff of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. As I am advised, when one looks at the Heritage Act in relation to clause 222 there is a limited range of powers which may be otherwise exercised by the Minister which could be delegated to the chief executive officer or a member of the staff of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. In other words, I take it that the Minister retains the powers and the delegations are constrained by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is reassuring. Thus the issue of principle, which I raised at some length, remains. I do not wish to restate it but I do say that the Opposition believes that this amendment is necessary in the interests of proper government administration. It comes down to a view of government. By the way, I do not believe that the delegations are essential to the adequate or proper functioning of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). The functions which we discussed on previous days in the Committee are functions which can be exercised whether or not this clause or the ones following remain or go. This seeks to widen the ambit and powers of ATSIC. The functions which Senator Coulter and I discussed-welfare, housing and economic functions-are really not affected by this. As I mentioned earlier, there is a particular provision in the ATSIC legislation which relates to Aboriginal heritage matters. The Opposition will press its amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am still having some difficulty with the Opposition's amendments in this section. I have indicated already that I foresee some difficulty in relation to the operation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) in that it has a number of opportunities, powers and functions, some of which will be in conflict. The extension of that is that I foresee that it will be necessary sooner or later for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to re-establish a small department to provide advice separate from ATSIC. I believe that will probably eventuate. That will be the outcome of the evolutionary process to which the Minister has drawn our attention.

SPEECH.PARA: We are going into new territory with ATSIC and it is my prediction-and I believe the Committee's prediction-that a small department advising the Minister will become necessary. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not re-present the argument; it took too long and it is not fair to the Committee. But I think Senator Coulter's concern is well-founded. SPEECH.PARA: That does not mean that the argument which I have chosen to mount at this point of time is restricted to paragraph (c). There are two separate things. There is the matter of substance, to which I spoke at length and which Senator Coulter has said he recognises and has sympathy for; then there is the question of the particular amendment which would seek to prevent that particular delegation being made. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The reasons that I advanced earlier today, when arguing the matter on which we last divided-clause 222-apply also to clause 226. What this clause proposes is to give to the chief executive officer of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) or to a member of staff of that Commission certain delegated authority. It then has a further effect-in paragraph (c). I would like the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) to explain what the purpose of that paragraph is. The reasons that the Opposition advanced go to the proper relationship between the Parliament and a Minister of State and that Minister's department, and the proper relationship between that Minister and any officers of any statutory authorities under his control. Those reasons apply to this clause and this amendment as well.

In relation to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act, I raise a couple of matters. Several of us were in the Parliament when that legislation passed and became an Act of the Fraser Government. I was a member here at that time, with Senator Chaney, and we worked hard to get that piece of legislation accepted within our own Party and passed through the Parliament. It has been very major and very important legislation. We have, as it were, a proprietorial interest in the way it works. When I was Minister I had to administer the legislation, and Senator Chaney did the same. I was able to appoint Sir William Kearney as Aboriginal Land Commissioner, and I had dealings with Mr Justice Toohey, who is now a judge of the High Court of Australia, when he was the Land Commissioner. It was a most important piece of legislation. It is proposed here that certain functions under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act should now be delegated to officers of ATSIC. This is a matter which is properly for the Minister and his Department.

I have to make a couple of sad comments. Recently we have seen the Aboriginal Land Rights Act performing less well than we had hoped. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) quite recently refused to proclaim certain amendments to the Land Rights Act made in 1987. Those amendments are of interest for my colleagues in the Northern Territory, and would have sought to have excluded stock routes and reserves from claim. They passed through the Parliament, but they have not been proclaimed. The Minister's failure to proclaim those amendments was, in fact, a repudiation of a promise made by his predecessor in the office of Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It is a matter of great regret to this side of the Parliament that Mr Holding's promise, when presented to Parliament in legislative form and when passed by the Parliament as an Act of this Parliament, was not then proclaimed by the present Minister, Mr Hand. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Government agree that the decision to subsidise the major banks to prevent a further rise in their home mortgage rates will put extra pressure on building societies, which are now at a competitive disadvantage compared with the banks? What, if anything, does the Government have in mind to prevent what seems an inevitable rise in the home loan interest rates of those societies and other home-lenders not included in yesterday's deal which provide home finance for hundreds of thousands of Australians?

—I do not agree with Senator Chaney. What happened yesterday in respect of the banks was that the Reserve Bank of Australia changed its method of setting the interest rate it pays on non-callable deposits. Ever since non-callable deposits were introduced 12 months ago, the banks have been arguing for a change to the method of setting the rate. In fact, the Reserve Bank has been enjoying a windfall gain from the banks. It enjoyed that windfall profit as market rates rose. The decision simply corrects that situation. In so far as the banks and building societies are concerned, the situation has always been different with banks since the non-callable deposits replaced the statutory reserve deposits. The result of that for the banks has been a rise in interest rates which has significantly increased the cost to banks. As I understand it, that has not happened in respect of building societies.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the fact that at least one bank spokesman has already claimed an improved competitive position for the banks in terms of the home loan market, does the Minister deny that a subsidy or an improvement in the position of one sector of the home lending market does change the competitive position with respect to the balance of that market? Is the Minister denying that this will have any impact on the building societies?
—I am not. What I am saying is that the banks' less competitive position-a result of the system which has been in place-has been corrected. That is all.
—This will have no impact on the building societies?

—I am not saying that it will have no impact on the building societies, because if one lessens the uncompetitiveness of one sector which is providing housing loans, for example, then it makes a difference. But I am not saying that it will have an effect on building societies.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. What was the outcome of the recent International Union of Local Authorities conference held in Perth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to give the Senate a run-down on the outcome of this very important international conference. I know that Australian local government really welcomed the opportunity for Australia to host this international congress that focused on a range of issues affecting local government. I know that Senator Panizza, who was in Perth for one day of the congress and met with a number of representatives, agrees with me that it was a very important congress and we wish very much that we could have stayed longer.

ANSWER.PARA: What I would like to talk about today is the most important aspect to come out of the congress: the formation of the International Union of Local Authorities (IULA), Asia-Pacific region. It was inaugurated at this, the twenty-ninth, world congress in Perth. We welcome this establishment in the Asia-Pacific region and look forward, as a nation, to participating in that new region. The President of the new region is the Governor of Jakarta, Governor Wiyogo, and the Australian local government representative is the Vice-President of the new organisation, Mr Richard Maslan. Mr Richard Maslan has given sterling service in the work leading up to the hosting of the International Union of Local Authorities conference in Perth this year. The focus of the regional organisation is on training and development activities for local government in the region. Other IULA regional organisations have been established in Latin America, Africa, the east Mediterranean and the Middle East. The regional organisation will support at least one local government training and development centre at a location yet to be decided. The initial headquarters of the new organisation will be in Jakarta.

The Federal Government has supported this initiative because of its belief that the new organisation will contribute to the development of a regional identity for local government in Asia and the Pacific. Australian local government has much to contribute to and learn from such an organisation. In terms of local government training we, as a nation, have a great deal to offer Asian and Pacific countries and we look forward to establishing relations with a number of countries to further promote the needs of local government and, particularly, training in local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Minister confirm that yesterday's pre-election deal between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the banks offers no hope at all for an early reduction in the crippling interest rates now being paid by home borrowers and will have no effect at all on small businesses and others who are having to pay in excess of 20 per cent on overdrafts?

—First of all, nobody has said that the decision made yesterday will lead to an early reduction in interest rates. Anybody who has been following the debate on this issue knows that such a reduction is a concern of the Government and will happen when the demand in this economy is reduced. Yesterday's decision has nothing to do with that. Secondly, so far as small businesses are concerned, there is a difference between home mortgage rates and rates on advances or loans made by banks to small businesses. The Government does not wish to see the continuation of the rates which are now adversely affecting some small businesses. The fact of the matter is that the interest payable on loans to small businesses is tax deductable as a business expense; it is not tax deductable for people paying off home mortgages.
—It is in America and the United Kingdom.

—Lots of things happen in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. I am answering a question which Senator Alston directed to me about what is happening here. One can make all sorts of comparisons with the United States and the United Kingdom. I would not particularly want to be involved in trying to manage the economy of the United Kingdom at the moment, any more than I enjoy being a member of a government in circumstances involving higher interest rates. None of us enjoys that.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. It relates to the Australian creative artists fellowships. Is the Minister able to account for the fact that there are no women in the first round of fellowship winners? How can we ensure that there is proper recognition of the fact that the talents of Australian women creative artists are not inferior to those of men?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know that Australian women artists are not inferior to men. We know that Australian women artists are extremely talented. We know, from the fact that so few women applied for the first round of the fellowships, that Australian women artists are much more modest than Australian male artists. I do not know whether women on the other side of the chamber would agree with me, but perhaps that is a fair comment to make of Australian women generally. Perhaps they are, indeed, more modest.

ANSWER.PARA: The creative artists fellowships were announced in May. Awards to the seven most eminent artists were made to the Aboriginal playwright Jack Davis, the composer Richard Meale, author Frank Moorhouse, poet Les Murray, pianist Geoffrey Tozer, visual artist Ken Unsworth, and dancer and choreographer Garth Welch. The fellowship recipients were selected from a field of applicants who responded to advertisements in the national media. Overall, the Australia Council received 116 applications, of which only 36 were from women. The applications were assessed by an independent advisory panel comprising Professor Donald Horne-the Chairman of the Australia Council-Tony Bishop, Betty Churcher, Kelvin Coe, Rubin Fineberg, Ross Gengos and Mary Vallentine. In passing, I mention that Betty Churcher is the first woman director of an Australian State art gallery. She has just been awarded the 1989 Excellence in Management award for women, which indicates the increased recognition of Australian women in many fields of Australian life.

The fellowships were awarded on the basis of merit, as assessed against established guidelines and criteria by the advisory panel. After the announcement of the awards a number of women contacted me-not surprisingly-because women artists and women in the community were very concerned that not one women had been selected. As a result, I wrote to and discussed this matter with my colleague the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding. He advised me of the fact that there were fewer applications. The Australia Council has recently advised me that, as a result of its second round of advertisements for the fellowships, to be announced in October, there has been a significant increase in the number of women applicants. It is most welcome that, perhaps because of the publicity and the great deal of outspoken comment by women who were critical that not one woman had been selected, more women have applied for the second round.

It is also important to point out that within the Council as a whole, in terms not of fellowships but of applications and grants, there has been an encouraging trend in favour of women in 1988-89. Success rates for men and women are equal, as of course they should be. The average grant for women was slightly higher than for men this year. I take this opportunity to urge women artists not to be so modest and to consider applying for fellowships so that in future years there will be more equal numbers of applicants competing for these important fellowships.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the impending execution in South Africa of Mr Mangena Jeffrey Boesman? What action is the Government taking to seek clemency for Mr Boesman?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had reports that Mr Mangena Jeffrey Boesman is to be executed today in Pretoria in South Africa. He was accused with others of the murder of a teacher during one of the boycotts in October 1985. I am pleased to say in respect of the impending execution that last night the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, and the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Janine Haines, made a joint appeal to the State President of South Africa to grant clemency to him. No matter the circumstances, Australia is strongly and universally opposed, as everyone knows, to the imposition of the death penalty, which is an inhumane and degrading form of punishment in violation of the most fundamental of human rights, the right to life. The Australian Government regularly raises its concern over the death penalty with other governments.

ANSWER.PARA: The three party leaders noted in their joint statement that the execution of Mr Boesman would constitute a particularly severe injustice, given that his case was originally heard by a single judge and leave to appeal was refused. Mr Boesman and his fellow accused were also severely disadvantaged at the start of their trial in November 1986 by their lack of adequate legal representation, by the fact that state witnesses were part of the murder scene crowd, and that such evidence might well therefore be tainted by fear of the witnesses themselves being charged. It is a matter of great regret that three party leaders, not four, signed the statement. The National Party Leader, Charles Blunt, was approached with a view to his adding his signature to the appeal for clemency, but I understand he declined to do so. That speaks volumes about the attitude of the National Party not only to the death penalty issue, but also to the question of human rights generally in South Africa. The three party leaders who did sign the statement noted that the State President, in his inauguration speech, pledged himself to a quest for peace in South Africa through fairness and justice. The execution of Mr Boesman, if it proceeds today, would be seen by the world as the first political execution authorised by the new South African Government and prove a major blow to the prospects for peace and justice in South Africa.

I should say, just by way of a final point, that our ambassador in South Africa made representations to the office of the State President on behalf of Mr Boesman and three others scheduled to be executed for different offences. I note from press reports this morning that the death sentences on two of those others have been commuted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I heard the interjection before I rose. Ms Petra Kelly was critical of the Prime Minister and I think unfairly so. Nonetheless, her remarks on this subject are to be seen in the context of someone who is not necessarily uncritical of the Government. She argues-and this may be a contentious view-that therefore we do not need to go down the nuclear route. She sees the nuclear route as being more damaging. It is important to remind the Senate of what the Prime Minister said in his environment statement in July this year. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Following the call by the Toronto Conference in 1988 for a reduction in carbon dioxide emissions, the Government will carry out investigations and consult with relevant conservation and industry groups with the objective of achieving a global reduction in total greenhouse gas emissions. This will involve processes such as energy efficient manufacturing and vigorous moves to energy conservation in Australia and abroad.

Under the national energy research, development and demonstration program this year greater emphasis has been placed on the environmental impact of energy production and its use. Since the program began in 1978, $32m has been committed to projects on renewable energy, $30m has been committed to projects on energy efficiency and end use, and $500,000 has been spent on researching six projects concerning the greenhouse effect.

In December 1987 the Government announced that an additional $5m would be made available over five years for research on renewable energy, energy efficiency and energy conservation. An additional $500,000 in 1989-90 and $900,000 in 1990-91 has been provided for energy management programs. So we are an active government in terms of energy efficiency and energy management in Australia, following a route that has been advocated by a world-ranking environmental spokesperson.
