This is in contradistinction to a view put to this chamber by Senator Vallentine who, although a nuclear disarmament senator, has decided lately that her credentials should be green as well. She and Petra Kelly are not of the same mind on this subject. However, I welcome the involvement of Ms Kelly in this debate. It adds a context to and a more serious voice in the discussion of energy management matters in this country from an environmental point of view. It is consistent, I think, with the role played by the green independents in Tasmania, in working with the forestry industry, the trade unions and the Tasmanian Government in reaching consensus on the Salamanca agreement, which has enabled better management and utilisation of timber resources, taking into consideration environmental concerns in Tasmania. What was once said to be impossible-reaching agreement on that front-has now been achieved by virtue of that responsibility in government. It seems that Ms Kelly's attention to the process of government has led to a responsible approach being taken to these serious issues, and I commend that development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the open-ended commitment given by the Prime Minister more than two weeks ago to waive certain Civil Aviation Authority and Federal Airports Corporation charges equal to the payroll costs to the airlines of not standing down staff made idle by the pilots dispute, a commitment justified on the totally specious grounds that Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines are, for reasons of industrial reality, unable to proceed with such stand-downs. What is the taxpayers' bill so far as a result of the Government's gutless cave-in to the ultimatum of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that no unionist should be stood down?
—I will obtain an answer to that question as soon as I can. As I recall it, the figure was $3m a week. I will confirm that and between us we will be able to make the calculation.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support aware that the widely recognised emergency number 000 is not yet available in some areas of south-eastern Queensland? Is the Minister aware that in these areas valuable time is being lost in emergency, often life-threatening, situations because the caller is diverted to another number by a recorded message? Will the Minister request Telecom Australia to ensure that access to the emergency 000 number is made available to all Queensland residents without further delay?

—I certainly agree with Senator Colston that valuable time could be lost in an emergency situation if the caller is required, as is the case in certain areas of south-eastern Queensland, to ring another number. The area affected is the metropolitan urban fringe zones within the 075 area code, or at least the non-Gold Coast element of the 075 area. I am happy to say, however, that the situation should not continue for very much longer as the necessary technical work to provide the 000 service to this area is complete. It has not, however, been possible to commence providing the service due to an industrial dispute. This is the reason why callers to 000 in this area hear a recorded message advising them to call another number. Telecom has, I am advised, been actively pursuing settlement of the dispute, which is now expected to be referred to the Industrial Relations Commission for hearing. The service should be available within two weeks of the dispute being settled. Telecom is doing all it can to achieve an early resolution. I am informed that the only other area of Australia without current access to the 000 service is Kangaroo Island in South Australia, but that situation is expected to be rectified in mid-October this year.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, is about the unlawful payments of book bounty. The Minister may recall that he wrote to me on 7 September advising that a total of eight Commonwealth and State instrumentalities were the subject of exemptions under subsection 5 (8a) of the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 and naming those bodies. I remind the Minister that a direction for exemption is the only basis by which government instrumentalities, State or Federal, may become eligible to receive payments of bounty under the Act. Why, in 1987-88, did 12 government instrumentalities and why in 1988-89 did 11 government instrumentalities, all of which were not granted exemptions under section 5, unlawfully receive payments of book bounty? Why, for example, were payments totalling $237,132 made to the Australian Postal Commission in 1988-89?
—I do not have those details in my head. I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator.
—Mr President, I seek leave to table a copy of the Minister's letter to me.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. In June I wrote to the Attorney-General proposing a change in the management of domestic violence, particularly suggesting that violent men be removed from the home to a hostel under a restraining injunction and be provided with assistance to manage their violence. Can the Minister say what the Government's reaction to this proposal has been and whether that proposal has been listed on the agenda of a State and Federal Attorneys-General meeting? What, if any, has been the response? Would the Minister suggest that a pilot study be established to examine this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for her question. I certainly praise her ongoing concern about this very serious issue, which she raised in the chamber earlier this year. Domestic violence has traditionally been primarily the responsibility of State and Territory governments. Implementation of the honourable senator's proposals would therefore require action at the State level. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has written to his State and Territory counterparts setting out the honourable senator's proposal, urging them to consider seriously its merits and noting where their existing legislation already provides for victims to obtain injunctions or protection orders against offenders. It would seem that legislation in all jurisdictions already provides means to remove the violent offender from the home. The problem is, however, a perceived reluctance on the part of some to make use of existing remedies. In saying this, I am, of course, mindful of the fact that in some circumstances such remedies will not be suitable because the woman's fear is so great that she will feel safe only if there is no way in which the abuser can locate her.

ANSWER.PARA: In other situations, however, there would indeed be good cause to have greater recourse to powers that allow the perpetrator of the violence to be removed from the family home. This would ensure that the victims of such violence, nearly always women and children, would not be further victimised by being forced to leave their family homes, their schools and their communities. It would also ensure that the current costs to children, the family and society, the cost of shelters, new housing, moving and re-establishing, and the cost of single parent benefits and payments for children, would be reduced.

On the issue of enforcing available remedies, I am pleased to be able to report that in my State of Tasmania, the Attorney-General, Mr Peter Patmore, has responded to Senator Crowley's letter by taking action to increase the chances of magistrates ordering the offender to vacate premises in domestic violence situations. The Tasmanian Minister for Police and Emergency Services, Mr Ken Wriedt, has been requested to draw the availability of the option to request such an order to the attention of the police prosecuting section and all police officers who assist victims to apply for restraint orders.

The Tasmanian Minister for Community Services, Mrs Judy Jackson, has been requested to have the crisis intervention unit ensure that the availability of this option is made known to those private legal practitioners to whom the unit's clients are referred. I am also aware that Mrs Fran Bladel, as Minister Assisting the Premier on the Status of Women, is taking a close and personal interest in these initiatives in Tasmania. I congratulate the new Tasmanian Government on this prompt and sensible action and urge other jurisdictions to ensure that their legislation is properly applied so that in appropriate circumstances it is the perpetrators of domestic violence, and not the victims, who are removed from family homes.

Finally, the issue of providing alternative hostel accommodation for violent men and providing assistance for them to manage their violence is one which will obviously require a considered response. I am pleased to say that to date four State Attorneys-General have replied to Mr Bowen's letter. In each instance they have indicated that they have referred Senator Crowley's proposal to the appropriate person or body for further consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's claim yesterday that the Federal Government has realised its goal of eliminating child poverty in Australia. How is this reconciled with the report of the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, who found that 25,000 young Australians are homeless? Is the Prime Minister saying that none of those 25,000 are children? Or is he saying that none of them are living in poverty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to look at the historical context in which these remarks were made, what was said and what has happened since.
—It was a blatant election bribe and it has been shown to be so.
—Senator Puplick has touched me off on something which is very dear to his heart. It is the fact that in the 1987 election policy speech the Prime Minister said:

ANSWER.PARA: So we set ourselves this first goal: By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.
The supporting statement said:
We pledge that by 1990 no child will need to live in poverty.

Both statements were made on the same day. To implement that commitment, the family allowance supplement was introduced and benchmarks of adequacy were set for income support payments for low income families. Increases in both family allowance and the family allowance supplement announced in the April statement met these benchmarks in full from July 1989-six months ahead of schedule. To ensure that the purchasing power of these payments is maintained over time, the family allowance and the family allowance supplement rates will be adjusted annually to maintain those benchmarks. Income support arrangements for homeless young people are also being upgraded.
The Government has made this concerted attack on child poverty while the Opposition criticises, produces no alternative policies, and promises to slash welfare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish. The Opposition promises to slash welfare. The efforts of the Government in respect of this have been welcomed and applauded by the social welfare organisations around the country, including Bishop Hollingworth. Those opposite are concerned that they are not recipients of social welfare. Well, they probably ought to be-help the maimed and the blind over there. On 7 May 1989 Bishop Hollingworth had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: In strict economic security terms, it is true that the prime ministerial promise `that no children shall live in poverty by 1990' . . . will be achieved.
He is not a man who has been hesitant about criticising this Government and indeed all governments in relation to these matters. He went on to say:
For the first time in this country's history we have a system of guaranteed minimum income for children.
The pledge has been met in terms of the benchmarks in which it was originally framed. If those opposite read the Prime Minister's speech, they will see--

TALK.START.PARA: —You want them to sleep on benchmarks in the park.
—Order!
—I gather you have slept on some of--

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Puplick interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Puplick.

—If those people opposite read the Prime Minister's speech, they will see that the Government acknowledges that the causes and symptoms of poverty go beyond this. That is why in the 1989-90 Budget we also announced a $100m four-year package to assist disadvantaged young people, particularly homeless youth. That package includes substantial improvements in income support, more secure and long term accommodation for the homeless, and major education, training and labour market initiatives for young people.

ANSWER.PARA: If I might just offer a personal observation of homeless youth, it is this: while homeless youth may be in circumstances of some poverty at particular times in their lives, the fact is that it is an unfortunate and tragic social phenomenon which has been developing in this and other countries for a number of years. There is a variety of social causes of that. Rather than the shelling out of money and so on, people have to face up to the somewhat more complex issues in respect of these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you pretend you could get rid of if?
—There was no pretence to get rid of it, as Senator Alston said. I am grateful to Senator Reid for asking the question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WILD AND SCENIC RIVERS PROTECTION REPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources: Does he endorse the recommendations of the wild and scenic rivers protection report which he launched and which is aimed at the prevention of further degradation of the river systems of Western Australia? Will the Minister support those recommendations of the report which require action by the Commonwealth? Does the Minister stand by his statement which he made in Western Australia on 23 July 1989 that there are environmental matters of national and international importance where it is vital that the Commonwealth has explicit constitutional authority? Does the Minister consider protection of Australia's water resources to be of sufficient importance for the Commonwealth to exercise such constitutional authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins has again raised for public attention an important report prepared by a professional consultant to environmental groups-its proper title being the Conservation Council of Western Australia-into wild and scenic rivers in Western Australia. She is right: I was invited by that body to launch that report. I did so on one bright, sunny Sunday morning at the university boatshed on the lawns of the university-Senator Chaney was there as well-overlooking the banks of the Swan River.
—Did you go for a big row later on?

—I do not know what all this cacophony is for, but Senator Chaney was there and we both had a delightful morning, as did the representatives of the local councils that border on the Swan River. The report deals with an important issue, certainly from the point of view of Western Australian rivers. In the south-west of Western Australia rivers that once were fresh and flowed freely to the sea are now saline and in some cases show disturbing levels of pollution. The report asked for people to consider rivers in the context not only as transport or as sources of fresh water or irrigation but also in terms of their scenic beauty and the genetic diversity that they contribute to regions and catchments. It asked that the view be taken not just of the waterways themselves but of the riparian boundaries, that is, that a whole catchment view be taken. That is a very valuable contribution to the understanding and discussion of this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked whether I support the recommendations that have been made to the Commonwealth. I am aware of only one recommendation, which is to provide for the establishment of long term management plans which would bind the Commonwealth and local government authorities and the public. The Commonwealth Government has long term management plans for rivers that cross more than one State. The Murray-Darling Basin is a good example of cooperative federalism in which the Commonwealth Government and the governments of three States-New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia-work together to manage that river system on a whole catchment basis. But, if the river systems involved are within one State, under the Constitution we do not have any direct authority over them.

I was asked directly by Senator Jenkins whether we would seek, obviously in certain circumstances, to exercise certain rights and she quoted a statement I made on 23 July. I made that statement on the basis that we were then negotiating with the New South Wales Government an agreement for the management of the south-east forests of New South Wales. At that time it was particularly important for me to make it clear and on the public record that, if there were not a cooperative outcome of those negotiations, the Commonwealth Government would look at what constitutional rights it could exercise to bring about an outcome that the community of Australia wanted. I do not resile from that. I am pleased to say that the Prime Minister also made a strong statement on that basis some weeks later. This Government does not resile from that. I am absolutely certain of Senator Richardson's view. None of us run away from that; we stand by those undertakings. If Senator Jenkins's question invites me to say there is some basis for exercising those constitutional powers in Western Australia, I do not see that. Far and away the best model is to pursue the cooperative approach, negotiate a workable arrangement and work together to implement those policies. If the cooperative approach does not work and there is a real problem that needs to be addressed, this Government has never walked away from taking the strong course, as it did in the Tasmanian dams case in 1983.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIRLINE PILOTS DISPUTE: USE OF DEFENCE FORCE AIRCRAFT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In asking this question I endorse the wide appreciation, which has been expressed by travellers, of the cheerful and efficient service provided by the Defence Force during the airlines dispute. But is it correct that the Royal Australian Navy is about to withdraw from the civilian airlift due to pressing service needs? Does the Minister agree with the reported remarks of the Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal Funnell, that the use of the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) in flying domestic passengers during the airlines dispute has distorted Air Force operations? If the Minister has not seen that report, I am happy to table it. For how much longer will the Australian Defence Force be able to continue the airlift? Is this an open-ended requirement or has the Government set a deadline for when the Services are to return to their proper role?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that Senator Newman has finally come out and said something nice about the efforts of the Air Force over the last six weeks, as it has done a tremendous job.
—I have been doing it constantly. Where have you been?

—I have been doing it in here. I do not know where Senator Newman was. She has been silent as usual. However, as I have said, I am delighted that Senator Newman takes that attitude, finally. As far as I am aware, no deadline has been set by the RAAF or the Government for pulling out of the assistance being given during the pilots strike. I shall endeavour at the end of Question Time to see whether there has been a change in that but I am pretty sure that is right. As far as the Navy is concerned, I am not aware of what Senator Newman raised but I will certainly check that as well. The RAAF can continue this service for quite some time to come. Obviously, it means a change in the way in which the RAAF operates, but that is not insurmountable for the Government or for the RAAF.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Is the Minister aware of reports that violent clashes are likely this weekend in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales between timber workers and conservationists? Is there any action available to the Federal Government which would head off or prevent this violence? Is the Government concerned that any such violence would stand in the way of attempts to settle the south-eastern forest issues on a fair, sensible and cooperative basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of reports that demonstrations have been planned for the south-eastern forests this weekend and of reports, when demonstrations have occurred in that area in the last few weeks, that violence was involved in those demonstrations. That is an extremely unfortunate outcome and action should be taken to prevent it. The essential points are, from the forestry side, that there were reports of human faeces being spread on forestry workers' cars and offensive behaviour towards forestry workers and, from the demonstrators' side, that there were reports of demonstrators being punched and, in one case, which I saw on television, of a demonstrator being forcibly dismounted from a protest that he was conducting about access to parts of the forest. All of those things are unfortunate. But I uphold absolutely, the right of the demonstrators to make their point of view heard and to conduct their demonstrations. That is a fundamental right that this Government will stand by.

ANSWER.PARA: The critical thing is that this Government has concluded with New South Wales an agreement which would enable flora and fauna studies to be conducted and for decisions then to be made about how the maximum utilisation of the forest resources can be arranged, consistent with our environmental objectives. Therefore, the industry and environmental objectives can be met. We have released a study into flitch mills and a study into the better utilisation of small and round wood. We will soon be announcing something on the plantation front. We are trying to compose a community group to advise us from all aspects of the community-environmentalists, workers, industry and foresters-on how we should deal with the outcome of those studies. Therefore, we are in transition from the old way of managing the forest to a new, more enlightened way in which we will manage it better, more efficiently and with foremost in our minds the environmental values as well as balancing those against the timber production values. We are looking at setting a course to move into downstream processing. It will take a while, as we are in transition, for the fruits of that transition to be realised and for the serious approach that we have adopted to be seen as the right approach. In this context, people who have misgivings about our role have a right to demonstrate. They should do that if they feel that way. But it is desirable that some basis of cooperation between the demonstrators and the workers be arrived at. The timber industry workers union has expressed to me its concerns about its membership being used as the meat in the sandwich. I understand its concerns. I also understand how demonstrators, in putting their view in a very emotional situation, can also suffer some danger.

As a consequence, in the hope of getting both the protesters and the workers together, I have begun to explore to try to find a process in which the demonstrations can proceed but the work can proceed without there being violence and without there being conflict. I am doing this so that the points of view of both groups can be properly viewed and aired as a contribution to the democratic institution that we hold dear in this country. I think there are prospects for that kind of achievement from this type of exploration which I am involved in now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to recent press speculation stating that the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd and the National Australia Bank Ltd are considering a merger. In view of the fact that Australians are now serviced by only four major banks, reduced from seven-the English, Scottish and Australian Bank Ltd, the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd and the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd having been absorbed-will the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government is in favour of an amalgamation that will further deprive Australian borrowers and lenders of a choice and of competition within the banking system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really cannot comment on what is speculation about a proposed merger.
—Are you in favour of a merger?
—I would, of course, not want to make a judgment without understanding the proposed facts. Let me say that it is not correct to say that Australia is served by only four banks--
—I said four major banks.
—There are more banks here than there have been for a very long time.
—But not in the retail area.
—There are some in the retail area and the honourable senator as a traveller in Queensland might observe that in some country towns.
—If he ever gets out of Brisbane.

—I do not know whether that is true. But if Senator Boswell goes out into country towns in Queensland he will see that there are more retail banks than four. The second point I make about the possibility of a merger of two large banks into one is simply this: the banking business is increasingly international. It is strongly arguable that Australia's best interest is served by having banks with sufficient critical mass to operate competitively internationally as well as in the Australian market. Indeed, as we know-or I hope Senator Boswell knows-banks like Westpac Banking Corporation and the ANZ Bank are operating in a number of countries.
—All but the Commonwealth Bank.

—They are international in their ramifications. On the other hand, if we look at the list of large banks throughout the world we will find that the list is highly dominated by Japanese banks with a decline in the relative size of American banks. In that circumstance I think it is probably a good thing if Australia has some banks of sufficient size to be able to operate and stand on their own feet in the international marketplace. That ramification has to be considered as well as the question of more parochial--
—Are you arguing for a merger?
—I am not arguing anything. I am just trying to explain a few facts which have to be considered.
—I am having difficulty understanding where Senator Button is going.
—I am not going anywhere.
—Is the Government in favour of a merger or is it not in favour of a merger?
—I am not making any pronouncement on that question. It might be helpful if I explain the process.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable senators will just listen for a moment, I want to help them think the matter through. Before saying that we can make a judgment about that question we have first of all to look at what we are actually confronted with, with the exception of a couple of rumours in newspapers. Secondly, we have to look at the proposal. Thirdly, we have to take a number of factors into account. The implications of this question are very parochial, if I might say so. Other issues than those raised in this question have to be taken into account before any thoughtful or intelligent government, such as we happen to have here at the moment, makes any pronouncement on this issue. Senator Boswell might have difficulty understanding that but that is why he and the Opposition are over there and why we are over here.

—I do not want you to say that it is not in the best interests of Australia when it happens and wring your hands after it happens. That is what you said about Coles and Myer: it was not in the best interests of Australia.
—Senator Boswell is trying to be kind and he is concerned about my emotional condition.
—We are all concerned about your condition.
—I am concerned about the intellectual condition of the honourable senator. That is something we have to be concerned about at all times when confronted with this Opposition.

—Earlier in Question Time Senator MacGibbon asked me a question in which he sought clarification of what he described as the Prime Minister's assertion that about 50 per cent of the capacity of flights would be used in the Australian airlines system by tomorrow. We may have been at cross-purposes. On the basis of Senator MacGibbon's question I thought he was asking whether 50 per cent of commercial aircraft-Australian Airlines Ltd and Ansett Airlines of Australia-would be in service by tomorrow. As I understand it the Prime Minister said that we would be operating at 50 per cent of the capacity normally supplied by the airlines. In fact, 50 per cent of the capacity normally supplied by the airlines is available at the present time and is made up of international aircraft, and Royal Australian Air Force and other domestic planes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday Senator Sheil asked me a question concerning Japanese fishing in Australian waters. I am now in a position to add further to my answer. In response to Senator Sheil's question on Japanese fishing activity in Australian waters I am afraid that the honourable senator has been provided with some rather dubious facts. In an endeavour to clarify these issues, the following information is provided: Japanese fishing boats are permitted access to Australian waters under a bilateral agreement negotiated annually. These boats fish using long-lines which are set to target tuna and billfish. Japanese boats do not trawl in Australian waters. During the 1988 bilateral negotiations, Australia gave notice that the current 12 nautical mile exclusion zone would be expanded to 50 nautical miles off the east coast from 1 November 1989. This will be further discussed at this year's bilateral negotiations, scheduled for next month, and Australia will stand firm on its position.

ANSWER.PARA: While the Australian fisheries remain largely inshore operations, which is especially the case for the tuna fishery off Queensland, and Australian fishers do not fully utilise fishing resources currently utilised by the Japanese, Australia is required by international law to give Japanese boats access to Australia's waters, always subject to sound resource management.

Australia receives a number of benefits from allowing Japanese access to its waters. In addition to payment of an access fee of $3.392m, benefits include: direct benefits to Australian fishers through logbook information compiled by the Japanese. This is available to both commercial and recreational fishers. Logbook information is also important to Australian scientists as a means of collecting and supplementing research data on fish stocks and Japanese boats have access to Australian ports which has direct benefits to those local communities and to Australia as a whole.

Finally, I should report to the honourable senator that the assertions made about these matters by some individuals have been disclaimed by the Australian Recreation and Sport Fishing Confederation which, in a supportive letter to me on 22 September, stressed the continued need for negotiation rather than confrontation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a further response to a question from Senator Panizza yesterday about incidents of air safety.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

I am now in a position to respond further to a question asked without notice by Senator Panizza about reports of incidents related to air safety, particularly in regard to the greater use of smaller aircraft.

I am advised that the Civil Aviation Authority has taken a number of initiatives to increase its surveillance of maintenance and flight operations of aircraft during the current disruption to airline services, and to raise the level of awareness of operators and flight crew to the need for additional care and vigilance in present circumstances.

On 8 September 1989 the Authority advised all operators and flight crew that additional surveillance is being undertaken and requested the co-operation of all operators in applying both the spirit and the letter of safety regulations.

On 22 September the Authority issued a Safety Promotion Circular asking all pilots to be meticulous in flight procedures and take account of the greater number of aircraft operating in their vicinity.

In relation to the specific questions asked by Senator Panizza, additional surveillance of small aeroplanes is being undertaken by CAA staff and as previously mentioned operators and flight crew have been made aware of this increase in surveillance activity.
Similarly, increased surveillance of flight crews is being undertaken to check that pilots are complying with limitations on flight and duty hours for flight crews.

Safety regulations do not permit pilots to fly unfamiliar aircraft. If pilots are being required to do this, as Senator Panizza has suggested, it would be a clear breach of the regulations. However the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation advises that there is no information available to it to suggest this is happening.
Some pilots may be flying to unfamiliar locations but this is a quite normal situation that pilots are trained to handle.

With regard to air safety incidents, the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation advises that there has been an increase in the total number of incidents reported, but this is in a situation where there has been a large increase in the level of activity.
The majority of reported incidents have involved smaller aircraft and resulted from flight crew errors, rather than problems with the air traffic services system.

The Bureau advises that in the past three weeks there have been some five occasions where aircraft have come into close proximity with each other. None of these incidents involved foreign or airline management pilots, or major passenger aircraft.
The Bureau has been informed of three instances where complaints were made regarding the command of English by foreign pilots. The incidents were minor in nature.

The Civil Aviation Authority advises that in instances of which it is aware where some language difficulties were experienced, the foreign pilots were flying at the time under supervision of competent English speaking pilots.
The Authority further advises that difficulties in radio transmission involving pilots are everyday occurrences among Australian flight crews.

The overall picture is that while the volume of air traffic, especially of smaller aeroplanes, is much higher than normal, initiatives have been taken to alert operators and flight crews to the need for extra vigilance and increased surveillance of maintenance and flight operations is being undertaken by the Civil Aviation Authority.
Sitting suspended from 12.59 to 2 p.m.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Bishop proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The action of the Prime Minister in misleading the Australian people by claiming that the Federal Government has eliminated child poverty in Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has arisen and needs to be debated today because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in the most extraordinary way, has claimed and has been duly reported as claiming that child poverty in Australia has been wiped out. In the terms of this debate we are saying that, in so saying, the Prime Minister is misleading the Australian people. We ought not to be surprised at that, of course, because he continually misleads the Australian people with regard to both the pilots strike and keeping down the interest rate for home loan mortgages. But in this serious matter of child poverty, quite clearly the Prime Minister is misleading by a clever interplay of words.

SPEECH.PARA: Today in Question Time, in answer to a very important question from my colleague, Senator Reid, Senator Button told us that we really had to look at the Prime Minister's promise in the historic context in which it was made. Let us do that. It was a promise made in 1987 in the lead-up to the 1987 election-just as we are now in a lead-up to the 1989-90 election. The catchcry of the 1987 election speech made at the Sydney Opera House was, `There will be no child poverty in Australia by 1990'. That is the historical context-a promise made by the Prime Minister to the Australian people in 1987. Yesterday he had the audacity to say that he had eliminated child poverty six months in advance of the target. He is not only a miracle worker in that he can achieve what Senator Button admitted this afternoon was a growing problem but also he said, `We have got rid of it six months ahead of target'.

There has been a lot of talk about benchmarks. I will put the benchmarks into context because apparently the evidence for saying that child poverty has been abolished is that the Government has met its benchmarks by which it determines whether people are poor or not poor. There are plenty of marks on benches where homeless children live and I would think that the marks on benches left by people who are poor, in poverty and without a home are far more important than the so-called arbitrary benchmarks which the Government chooses to take as the indicator of whether or not we have any poor children in this country. In fact, one could say that the rationale behind the whole statement is that if we abolish the word `poverty' we cannot have anyone living in it.

We come then to the question of who is a child. It is a very interesting question, because if one reads the all-important Burdekin report-the benchmark report, shall we say, that came down as an indictment of the Government's policies in this country-one finds that a child is not a child when it is seven, eight, nine or 10; it is still a child when it is 15 or 16, or perhaps in some people's eyes, a child is still a child at 18 or while it is still, or ought to be, the responsibility of its parents. The report stated that there were a known, recognised, identifiable 20,000 children or young Australians who are homeless but that the figure could be as great as 70,000.

This report is not ancient; it is an up to date report and it is signed and dated 10 February 1989. What an amazing thing that on 10 February 1989 we still had children in poverty! But at the end of September 1989 the Prime Minister said, `Are we not terrific? We have abolished child poverty six months ahead of schedule in that magic period between February 1989 and September 1989'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Easter bunny came then.

—The Easter bunny came. There had to be a good reason; that is as good a reason as any. Let me go back to what Senator Button had to say earlier today. He was hard to hear because the idiocy of many of the statements he made was drowned out, I suspect by people who were reacting in a most predictable way. But he did say that the causes of poverty were many and that it was a growing problem. Indeed, as early as the late 1970s we were starting to identify the numbers of poor young Australians-they were being recognised as a real and important factor.
—Are you saying that they had no money?

—I will come to that in a minute. It was revealed in this very chamber that, by 1980, 15,000 young Australians, all living in Melbourne, were identified as roaming the streets of Melbourne without any home or source of comfort and succour.
—He told us that was temporary.

—Of course the Prime Minister told us that it was temporary but these figures were revealed in 1980. It was temporary right up until February 1989 but somehow in the last six months we have found the magical solution. As I said earlier, we might find a solution by changing the terminology and somehow getting rid of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go back to what Senator Button had to say. He said that we needed education to help overcome this problem. I could not help wondering whether what he really meant was a bit more propaganda. This Government is very good at propaganda; it has a whole department called the National Media Liaison Service-`aNiMaLS'-which is good at propaganda. It spreads a story with great zeal. But on the question of education, perhaps all these homeless young Australians have to be told that they are no longer living in poverty because, clearly, they do not know it. But if we had a good, decent bit of propaganda we could tell them that they were no longer living in poverty. Furthermore, we could tell them that they ought to be grateful to this Government because they are no longer living in poverty. So if they could possibly manage to get themselves to the ballot box on 2 December, or in February or March, or whenever the election is going to be, they could be properly grateful and cast a vote for the great Prime Minister who tells us that he has wiped out their poverty. So education is very important. We had better watch out for the consultant who is employed to write that propaganda or education program and we had better watch out for those lower House Labor Party members who use their $30,000 a year to mail that propaganda to these poor unfortunate children who have no homes. Maybe it is hard to send a letter to them but perhaps we could go round the streets of Melbourne, Sydney and other capital cities and hand them pamphlets that would make them feel better because, quite clearly, the policies of the Government do not make them feel better.

There was one thing that made me very angry as I read the report of what this wonderful Prime Minister had to say. Having said that he had abolished all child poverty he then admitted that there was a need for a broader assault on the problem of youth homelessness. Who on earth does he imagine the homeless youth are if they are not the children of this nation? He called for cooperation, mind you, between State and local government and welfare organisations to cure the problem of homeless youth. Do honourable senators have the picture? He personally, single-handedly like Merlin the Magician, wiped out child poverty but the problem of homeless youth remains. To cure that problem the Prime Minister needs the help of the States, local government and welfare organisations. He did not need any of that help before to wipe out child poverty six months in advance of schedule because those benchmarks that had been set had nothing to do with people. They had to do with being smart. His exact words yesterday were as follows:
At the outset of the last election campaign, I committed a re-elected Labor government to an ambitious and proud goal: the elimination of child poverty in Australia.
He went on to say that his Government-and I quote:
had eliminated the financial need for any Australian child to live in poverty.

Does anyone know what that means? It means that if anyone lives in poverty now it is his fault; it is not the Government's fault. The Government has met the benchmarks. Those same poverty stricken, homeless children living on benches and making their mark in parks and on the streets could say, `Thank you, Prime Minister. You have eliminated my financial need to live in poverty. It is clearly my fault. I apologise to you for being an embarrassment to you'.

Let us look at what Burdekin said in his report which bears the date February 1989. As I said, he readily identified that there were 25,000 young Australians without a home. I do not know about anyone else but if I knew of a child without a home, that child would, in my view, live in poverty, penury and in pretty dire straits. The report revealed a depressing picture of sleeping in the open, ill health, prostitution, drugs and violence. Do not those things constitute poverty? I would have thought so. The report said that there can be up to 70,000 children and young adults living in a vicious circle of poverty and coping with the prejudices that prevent them from getting permanent accommodation and work and placing them at physical and psychological risk. That has all been eliminated in the time between February 1989 and September 1989, has it? How would we measure such a thing? What is the basis for the Prime Minister telling us that these people fundamentally do not exist anymore? Where are the studies? Where is the methodology? Where is the work? The answer is that there is not any. The answer is that the evidence is in reports such as the Burdekin report. This report sets out quite clearly the sort of methodology we have to use to measure these things. Page 351 of the report talks about methods of estimating the number of homeless young people. It sets out three very direct and methodological systems for determining just who those people are and for counting them.

Where is the statistical base for the Prime Minister's assertion that all poverty for children in this country has gone? As I said, it has not. It is all dependent on clever wording. It is dependent on the clever wording that says that his Government has eliminated the fundamental need for any child to live in poverty because it met its own arbitrarily placed benchmarks. In terms of how children live or survive if they have been forced out of their home because their parents have broken up, because they are bashed or suffering other hardship, and they are forced to live on the streets, there is no program, no solace and no answer from this Prime Minister for those children. But there are from some of those others that he was imploring to help-the State governments. In New South Wales, Minister Chadwick has changed the name of her department from youth and community services to family and community services because she realises that if we are going to eliminate child poverty, it has to begin with families. Parents have to care for their children. Burdekin found that of those children who live on the streets the largest identifiable group is children who have come from broken families. We often hear the catchcry that there are sole parent families, that these are the children of sole parents. I do not know about anyone else, but I find that an absolute mystery. I do not think we have had a sole parent for 2,000 years. As far as I am aware, it takes two parents to bring children into the world, and two parents have responsibility for those children.

We put in place through this Parliament legislation which put very strong and grievous strains on marriage so that our divorce rate escalated for two decades in a very strong and disappointing way. The fallout has been a growing number of homeless children. In New South Wales Virginia Chadwick has been running some splendid programs and assisting to find accommodation for these homeless children. To her dismay, within the last two or three weeks it came to her attention that an interview had been given by a member of Minister Staples's staff, Mr P. Ormonde, in a magazine called Rolling Stone, in which he got stuck into the work that the State governments are doing, saying that they have to get hold of these children because the States are only providing shelter for them and that they cannot get their hands on them early enough. I will not insult the Senate by reading the language that is contained in this particular article, but if one thinks that Australian children would be well served by being put at the tender mercies of somebody who uses the language that is contained in this particular article, one would have a different idea of care for children than I would.

The tragedy for children, of course, is that they cannot vote; they cannot voice their opinion. They are being treated as commodities by this Government. They are being treated as political ploys. In an emotional outburst we had the promise that child poverty would be eliminated by 1990, and in an outrageous speech yesterday Mr Hawke claimed that he had done it. I think one of his problems is that he has started to believe his own hand-outs. He has started to believe that, somehow, this country is in decent shape; it is not. Interest rates for home mortgages are sending people backwards. People on talkback radio are ringing up and saying, `We have to live on bread and butter'. Reports are coming out that more than one-third and up to 40 per cent of incomes of households are used to meet mortgage repayments. We are not seeing the abolition of child poverty in Australia; we are seeing the creation of a whole new category of poverty for children in Australia.

It could even be called genteel poverty, because children can be added to the list who are living at home with their families, with a roof over their head, but unable to eat a decent meal through the week. These people are not going to cry for hand-outs because, by and large, these are people with pride, who believe that by dint of effort and hard work they can provide for their families. Yet it is government policy that, far from reducing child poverty, is indeed adding to the burden. The children I talk about, the children referred to in the Burdekin report, are children who are without people to care for them. They are suffering the double penalty of living in poverty and living without care and without love. But there are other children who live in poverty. They are children who are much loved and much cared for by people who feel hopeless within the situation that this Government has created.

I am sure that when Government senators speak in this debate they will tell the Senate about the fantastic policies they have put in place, meeting their wonderful benchmarks and how everything in the garden is rosy. They will not tell us about the lack of pride; about the times of weeping in a private household over an inability to cope; about the people who fall outside the guidelines of the benchmark, the people who make up the fibre of this country. The Prime Minister's promises all have the hollow ring of the abolition of child poverty six months in advance of target. So do the other policies he has put in place. Australians-and Australian children in particular-deserve a better go. Indeed, they deserve a change of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I walked into the Senate this afternoon I was quite calm about this debate, but I am extremely angry. I am angry at the hypocrisy that has driven Senator Bishop this afternoon and the fact that she is presuming that people out there do not remember and cannot read or understand. What hypocrisy to come in here and pretend to be the caring side of politics when, if one looks at Senator Bishop's record and her promise not only in this Parliament but in the State Parliament, one sees the emptiness and vacuousness of her argument. For a start, let us put on record very clearly and properly what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said yesterday. For those out there who may in fact be listening--
—What did he say in 1987?

—The young fellow should get back to Sesame Street. Let us put on record what the Prime Minister said yesterday and what he has said on this issue. The simplest answer to the matter of public importance raised by Senator Bishop is to quote what the Prime Minister said yesterday. In doing so, let me give a complete record, unlike the one that has been presented to the Senate this afternoon by Senator Bishop, and also unlike the one that has been printed in the Australian this morning, where parts of the speech were printed as if they flowed on but where specifically important parts were omitted. Let me read what the Prime Minister said yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset of the last election campaign, I committed a re-elected Labor Government to an ambitious and proud goal: the elimination of child poverty in Australia.
Then there is the paragraph that was missed today by Senator Bishop and by Suzanne McDonnell in the Australian this morning and by others:
We set ourselves historic benchmarks of support that would be available to low income families in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I talked at great length about your benchmarks.

—Of course Senator Bishop talked about the benchmarks. Let me tell her about the importance of the benchmarks to indicate the ignorance, irrelevance and unresearched nature of her position. The benchmarks were not set by the Government but were a result of several years of research and analysis by the social security review. They have been adopted by the Government, the first government to establish benchmarks of adequacy for child payments. When they were adopted there was not one word of criticism from those opposite as to their adequacy or relevance. Let us get that on the record. Let us not talk about these benchmarks as arbitrary. Senator Bishop just demeans her own position. Let me continue to read what the Prime Minister said.
—But did your own Minister--
—Just shut up for a second and let me finish my speech.
—Order! Senator Bolkus is speaking.
—The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Since our re-election we have, as you understand perhaps better than most-
this is to the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS)-

acted with determination to reach that goal. In December 1987, we introduced the family allowance supplement as a first and substantial stage towards our benchmarks. Since then, we have progressively increased family allowances and the family allowance supplement-most recently in the April statement this year. As a result, the benchmarks we set ourselves were attained six months ahead of schedule.
As well, we have directed new levels of assistance to those who are renting their accommodation on the private market.
I remind honourable senators that this is the completeness of the Prime Minister's speech. He continued:

Housing is always a large component of expenditure-especially for those renting privately who have the added knowledge that with each rent payment, they are not, unlike home buyers, at least acquiring an asset in the form of a family home. So since coming to office we have trebled rent assistance.
As a result of these decisions-
this is a vital part-

a single family earning $320 a week, with three children, now receives from the Federal Government $109 a week-by any standards a very substantial boost to the family budget. Because it is free of tax, it is equivalent to a wage rise of $167 a week-better than a 50 per cent pay increase. And because family payments and rent assistance are indexed, the economic security of recipient families cannot be eroded by inflation.
Through the Child Support Agency, we are also ensuring that parents coping alone with the responsibility of bringing up children actually receive child maintenance payment from their former spouse.
So the totality of the picture is that we have created a system that directs financial resources, in very substantial quantities, to over 500,000 low income families.
Some recognition of that may put some balance into Senator Bishop's contribution. The Prime Minister continued:

As Bishop Peter Hollingworth said last month, `For the first time in this country's history, we have a system of guaranteed minimum income for children. The Opposition sought to openly acknowledge the merit of such reforms and move towards a bi-partisan stance on welfare policies for children . . .'
The Prime Minister went on to say:
Regrettably, all we have heard from the Opposition about children in poverty is carping and sniping. As usual, there is no alternative policy coming from the Opposition.
They seem content merely to revel in the tragic facts of youth homelessness-each kid on the streets is to them another proof that Hawke has failed in his child poverty pledge.
The facts are as I have spelled them out. The pledge has been met in terms of the benchmarks in which it was originally framed.
But I don't want to leave the topic there.
It is possible to describe poverty in terms of dollars or cents, or lack of them.
And it is possible to attack it in terms of financial benchmarks, as we have done.
But the causes and symptoms of poverty are far wider than pure economics. The tragic problem of youth homelessness illustrates this.

We recently announced a youth social justice strategy-a $100 million package which includes substantial improvements to income support, more secure and longer term accommodation for the homeless, and major education, training and labour market initiatives focusing on the special needs of youth.

As always, when one looks at the total statement, one sees that the Prime Minister has been impeccably honest. Let Senator Bishop point to one word of that quote that is inaccurate. She cannot, because her position on this matter is very well reflected by the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson. The Opposition is at a major disadvantage in this area because Dr Hewson was due to address the ACOSS Congress in the morning session, straight after the Prime Minister, but he did not turn up. Dr Hewson told ACOSS that he could not get to Melbourne because of difficulties with the planes. Great! The reality was that he actually travelled to Melbourne the night before on a plane with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). I presume that Dr Hewson assumed that he did not recognise him, but he got to Melbourne the night before with Mr Brian Howe. He was in Melbourne. He lied; he did not care; he did not roll up; and he told ACOSS that he was not there but, in fact, he was in the same city and could very well have attended.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw the comment that the shadow Treasurer lied.
—Yes, that is an unparliamentary expression.

—I withdraw because it is an unparliamentary expression. The reality is that this person who pretends to put forward the Opposition's policy and to come forward in a spirit of honesty went to Melbourne with the Social Security Minister but told ACOSS that he was not there. Honourable senators can draw whatever interpretation they want from that. It shows me that the Opposition, once again, is showing the same degree of concern for people as it showed in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at the past. Opposition members come in here today and argue from a position of high moral ground and criticise the Government. Let us have a look at what they did when they were last in government. In seven years of government, the Howard-Fraser regime increased payments for children in low income families once. In the 1982 Budget the payment was increased from $7.50 per week to $10-the only increase for low income families in seven years. In every year of this Government it has been adjusted. The results of the previous Government's policy were quite devastating. There is no recollection of that at all by Senator Bishop-amnesia runs riot again. In 1976, 370,000 children were in low income families and no-one is proud of that number. By 1983 this had increased to 830,000. Under the previous Government the number of children in low income families increased by 50,000 a year and in the last year of its government increased by a massive 150,000.

In our term of government we have increased pension and benefit rates every year. In 1983, they were $10. In 1989, they have increased to $31 for younger children and $34.10 for older children. In 1990 they will go up to $35.25 for older children. Every year there is an increase, which has a major impact on this policy area, but no recognition is given to this at all. What have we got in response? We have got from the Opposition a policy mix which shows absolutely no concern for the people involved. Someone asked me earlier to go to the Prime Minister's pledge made in 1987, or earlier on. Let us have a look at it. Let us clearly set it out. It was clear and unequivocal. The policy speech said:
By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.

To this end, my government will establish a new program of family help-a program designed to lift more than one million Australian children into security and to help the more than half a million Australian families in greatest need, the hardest pushed, the most disadvantaged.

What has been said about this comment? The Brotherhood of St Laurence at the time said, `This pledge, the most specific social commitment of the century, has been the subject of an historic package to provide a guaranteed income for poor children'. In 1987, the Prime Minister's pledge was expanded. There he promised:

During Labor's third term an adequate living standard for children will be achieved by: raising child payments to ensure that the total assistance per child moves from its current level of 11 per cent to at least 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension; and ensuring that the aggregate payments for older children attain a benchmark of 20 per cent of the combined married rate.

It is not arbitrary benchmarks, as I said earlier, but it has been analysed and developed comprehensively by the social security review, which is not only nationally, not only domestically in this little area, but internationally respected. In response to that, once again, we do have endorsements that should be placed on the record in order to give a comprehensive and balanced approach to this problem. The Institute of Family Studies described Labor's commitments to these standards of adequacy as follows:

Probably most significant of all, the linking of the rates of payment for FAS to those for the married rate of pension . . . along with the widening of eligibility for low income working families effectively produces a guaranteed minimum income scheme for all children.

For the first time, children are being seen as important in our community. The Government has delivered in full on the Prime Minister's pledge. Combined family allowance and supplement payments have been increased since 1987. These payments now constitute 15.3 and 20 per cent of married rate pensions respectively. The benchmarks of adequacy have been achieved. A Bill currently before the Parliament provides for adjustment of family allowance supplement (FAS) each year to maintain these standards. The bottom line is that there are over 180,000 low income families on FAS and there are currently over 530,000 families with 1.1 million children benefiting under this Government's policy achievements. Compare that to 50,000 children every year thrown into the category of living in poverty under the previous Government. As the Prime Minister said in that statement from which I quoted earlier, it does not end there. It goes further. It goes into social infrastructure and employment. It goes into health policies, education policies and child care policies. In each area, this Government has made major achievements to the extent that they have been recognised. Bishop Hollingworth, once again from the Brotherhood of St Laurence, on 7 May-this is not for the information of senators on the other side, because they come in here quite blinkered, but for the people who might be listening-said:

In strict income security terms, it is true that the Prime Ministerial promise `that no child shall live in poverty by 1990' . . . will be achieved. This represents significant progress, and demonstrates that Government can meet some modest social justice objectives, even at a time of economic restraint when they are involved in public sector cutbacks and tax reductions in order to improve this economic efficiency.
He went on to say:

This pledge, the most specific social commitment of the century has been the subject of a historic package to provide a guaranteed minimum income for poor children whose parents earn less than about $300 a week.
He went on:
We congratulate the Federal Government on its work on child poverty, which represents a historic breakthrough in the national attack on child poverty.
This is an independent body, most deeply involved in the question. It is not operating from a biased perception or misrepresented motive as the Opposition does. He continued:
The Federal Government has now built a solid foundation of income security for Australian families.
I could go on but I would like to turn to the Opposition. I have dealt with its record and I now turn to its current promise. It tastes as sweet as sugar and smells of roses, as Senator Bishop does--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is stretching it a bit.

—It is, I suppose, but it has been a long day. Let us look at the reality. Senator Bishop talks about one State Minister. Let me deal with the Minister for Family Services in Queensland. Senator Bishop mentions one area of major priority, and that is sole income families. They are. Fifty per cent of children living in poverty in Australia are living in sole parent families. The Government has done something to help them. The child support scheme has the potential to assist hundreds of thousands of children in this category. It places a very clear and direct responsibility on the non-custodial parent to provide for the child's welfare and income. This scheme has increased the number of sole parent pensioners receiving maintenance by 40 per cent, and it has substantially increased the amount of that maintenance. It has been an historic and vitally important measure to help people in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: As of Sunday, the child support scheme, through stage 2, will apply, one would have hoped, to the whole of Australia-but it is not to apply in Queensland, the State where the Minister for Family Services has called upon the Federal Government to abolish the sole parent pension. It is a State Government with a policy steeped in prejudice and ignorance and which has absolutely no recognition of reality. It does not recognise that 80 per cent of sole parents have been in a marriage which has broken down and that only 2.8 per cent of sole parents are teenagers. It is a policy which gives no recognition of where those sole parents come from and the lives the kids in those families are living.

So the Minister for Family Services in Queensland wants to abolish the sole parent pension. Not only that, but also, because of a crisis in leadership and a crisis in government in Queensland, and a neglect of this area which has been common on that side of Parliament for years, it has not introduced legislation. One reason why it has not done so is that in 22 months there have been five different Ministers for Family Services in Queensland. The Government cannot get its Ministers together to agree to introduce legislation to provide assistance for children, under stage 2 of the scheme, specifically those whose parents have not married. That Minister is saying those people should be taken off the sole parent pension, and given nothing from the non-custodial parent because the Government in Queensland cannot get its act together. It cannot get its appointment secretaries together because its Ministers are changing so often. Agreement is reached between the relevant Ministers, and then the Ministers change. Today Paul Clauson is in, but the Minister with whom he made the last agreement is no longer in the relevant position, so there is no agreement.

Even if the Cabinet had considered the agreement, the Parliament in Queensland does not sit long enough to ensure that legislation could be introduced, let alone passed. So not only will kids in that State who are really in need not benefit from stage 2 of the scheme because of the ineptitude of the Government and the lack of concern on the part of the National Party of Australia in Queensland, but also it is that Government which calls upon the Federal Government to abolish the sole parent pension. This is the sort of attention, concern and respect that the Opposition gives to people in the community about whom it is making hypocritical statements in here this afternoon.

I return to the position adopted by Opposition spokespeople here. I quote from a statement of the Brotherhood of St Laurence issued on 20 August 1989. It congratulates the Federal Government for its commitment in the previous week's Budget to welfare reform. It says there is a need for a bipartisan policy in Australia, and expresses concern at the fact that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), in his reply to the Federal Budget, `made only passing reference to social welfare initiatives'. There was no reference to indexation, no commitment to it and no commitment that the Government's social welfare reforms will not be broken. All there was from the Opposition was the statement that it will massively reduce spending in the social welfare area. It cannot keep that promise and, at the same time, promise the world to people outside in this area. The Opposition is a fraud, it has been rejected as a fraud and, on this issue, the promise and commitment of the Prime Minister remains very clear to all of us in its totality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has raised today, as a matter of public importance, the following claim:

SPEECH.PARA: The action of the Prime Minister in misleading the Australian people by claiming that the Federal Government has eliminated child poverty in Australia.

The Minister representing the Minister for Social Security in this chamber, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), gave us the benefit of some detail, additional to that which we were able to read in the newspapers this morning, on what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said yesterday at the annual congress of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS). Unfortunately, I was not able to attend that congress due to the airline strike. I was offered a seat on the Prime Minister's plane but he was not coming back in time for me to attend this meeting of the Senate, so I could not accept it. Nevertheless, I think it is important that we address this question of child poverty. From that point of view, I certainly welcome the Opposition's bringing forward the matter. I will have more to say in a moment about what I consider to be the Opposition's role in all of this. Perhaps I will provide it with a further opportunity to play an even bigger role.

It was not only yesterday at the ACOSS congress that the Prime Minister promised to end child poverty. The Prime Minister and his colleagues subsequent to both the April statement this year and to the Budget this session said that at least the financial benchmarks had been met in the Government's proposal to eliminate child poverty and in its attempt to meet the Prime Minister's promise made before the last election. That part of his claim has received most media publicity. It is encouraging that the Prime Minister has now recognised the broader implications. Indeed, it is the first time that I have seen them on the record; it is good to have them on the record today in this debate. However, I think we need to look at the situation for children in this country. It is a fact that there are still children living below the poverty line. In sole parent families, if we use the latest poverty line figures and the latest figures that the Government has made available, we will still find that a sole parent with two children is $9.80-a significant amount-below the latest poverty line. A sole parent with one child would be $3.10 above the poverty line, a fairly tenuous non-poverty position, I suggest, and one that could very well mean that the person would be now below the poverty line, as would the family of that person, given the speed at which the cost of living is rising.

In many families-whether sole parent or otherwise; whether the parent is employed or unemployed-very speedy increases in costs of living, particularly housing costs, are causing quite large groups of families in various categories and at various stages to fall below the poverty line. The Government does not deny this, but it is galling, particularly for people who are working at the coalface, people whose daily work is in welfare agencies and other support agencies in the community dealing with these people, to hear constantly the political message given out that there is no problem or that there need not be any problem when they know very well there is. Certainly it is a matter of record that many welfare agencies and support groups in the community are finding their resources very hard-pressed to cope at this time. As Julian Disney said in the cover story in the Bulletin on 19 September, `the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting more numerous'. The report goes on to add to the reasons why this is happening. It states:

This is because there is some bottom-of-the-barrel bracket creep as the rising cost of housing creates a new class of working poor. Under these low income earners are the more traditional poor-the sole-parent families, the unemployed, the derelict, the young homeless and the remote community Aborigines.

In this debate let us not forget the Aboriginal poor who, as the cover story in the Bulletin reminds us, often have their problems compounded by cultural isolation and limited access to social services. Many of the problems of isolation also apply to non-Aboriginal families in remote areas. We cannot lose sight of the fact-and we should not lose sight of the fact-that even in financial terms there are families in which children are living in poverty. The major reasons for this still being the case have been outlined in many places. The documentation put forward in the promise the children campaign by the Brotherhood of St Laurence lists three major issues: unemployment, sole parent families and high housing costs. Clearly they are significant factors in creating poverty and in continuing to create poverty in our community.

We often hear from this Government about the jobs this Government has created. No doubt we will hear more in this debate about the increased numbers of jobs that have been created during the life of the Hawke Government. The Hawke Government needs to recall that under the Fraser Government the highest rate of unemployment was 6.7 per cent. Under this Government the highest rate is 9.8 per cent. It depends upon which particular statistics and which particular year one looks at. A major concern about the employment figures is that many of the new jobs that have been created have been part time or casual which, depending on family structure, can mean an enormous benefit, particularly to sole parent families where the only employment that can be found is part time. Sole parent families remain a major concern. I have already said that most of the children who are living in poverty, children who have not been advantaged significantly by government measures, are in sole parent families. The failure to increase and index the mother's guardian allowance-the only allowance which is exclusive to sole female parents-has been a major flaw in the whole family package which the Government has brought forward during its term of office. High housing costs remain a major concern. I will say something about that in a moment.

It is important that we recognise that it is no use taking a narrow view of what constitutes poverty in any respect-certainly not in respect of children. It is good to hear that the Prime Minister has put that view forward although it is perhaps on a slightly lower key than his claim of financial support. The Brotherhood of St Laurence, in its promise the children package which was launched by Mrs Hazel Hawke in May, while congratulating the Government as Senator Bolkus has reminded us at length went on to say:

The next step is for the Federal Government to reinforce this achievement with comparable progress in housing, employment and community services. Without this progress the income security reforms might be undermined.

That is the point upon which we need to focus in this question of getting children out of poverty and of building an Australian society in which no child will live in poverty. We heard that statement first from the Prime Minister in 1987. The Brotherhood of St Laurence goes on to say that much more beyond 1990 needs to be done.

This Government talks much about the social wage. A major feature of the Government's economic policy and action through the life of the Hawke Government has been based on the accord which establishes the social wage which is composed of a number of factors. It is composed not just of the financial pay packet that each worker gets; the social wage includes tax measures, family payments, including the rent assistance to which Senator Bolkus referred, as well as public community payments in health, education and housing. It includes the retirement package and so on. Under the accord the social wage is much more than what is in the pay packet.

The same applies to what we provide for our children. This was acknowledged by Mrs Hazel Hawke when she launched the promise the children campaign. She said that the campaign would seek promises of action from government, at both State and Federal levels, business and community groups and also individuals. She spoke of the need to build on the improved payments by arguing for better access to employment, housing and community services-a kind of accord; taking a social justice approach to child poverty.

We do not seem to be hearing this from the Opposition. It does not seem to have this approach. There is no recognition that we need to look at child poverty from a social justice perspective. In fact, when it comes to welfare payments and indeed social payments generally what we hear from the Opposition is all to do with spending cuts. Senator Bolkus has referred to some of those. Of course, the major proponents in the public domain in this area are our Senate colleague, Senator Stone, the shadow Minister for finance, and Dr Hewson who, when challenged constantly, says that under a coalition government government spending in these areas would be better targeted.

The Government responds usually through Mr Howe, the Minister for Social Security, by saying that we have the best targeted social security system in the world. Indeed, Mr Howe appears to be proud of that claim. I am concerned about that. When one looks at the broad issues and who is being targeted in the Government's very stringent social security system one sees it is sole parents; 45-year-old women who used to be on the class B widow's pension which was abolished; women who have not been in paid employment and who have somehow had to adjust their lives to that situation; young people in education and young people struggling to get into the work force; under 18-year-olds who have lost their unemployment benefits; and low income families generally in a range of ways.

Who then will the Opposition hit with its better targeting? It is very difficult to see who could not and who would not be hit.
