But if we look at the Opposition's general policies of deregulation and privatisation we see that the hits will clearly fall in the public services such as health, housing, education and even public services such as communications via Telecom Australia, Australia Post and all the rest. They will protest that they are providing better choice in the community but there is no real choice when one is poor. In the end there is only the choice of whether or not to eat. In many poor families, parents are going without so that their children can eat.

Where is the Opposition's record? Where are the Opposition's policies on social justice and a view of a child poverty accord that looks at the broader issues? Targeting creates poverty traps. I have heard nothing from the Opposition about how it would deal with that. We have seen government measures attempting to deal with that. But I put it to the Government that targeting can go too far and it can often be too difficult. If the Government wants to be miserly and wants to become an economic rationalist and a deregulator, then it will hurt people. Some of those people currently being hurt are the roughly 150,000 children still living in poverty. Australia in now actually spending less of its annual income on social security than when the Hawke Government took power-way below the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development level. We are not a welfare state.

I put it to the Government and the Opposition that this issue should not be a political football. There is a motion before this Senate for a joint select committee of all parties of this Parliament to address the issue of child poverty, to work further on the basis that has been set by the Brotherhood of St Laurence and others in the community, to come up with real solutions and real programs to take us into the 1990s, as Mrs Hawke has suggested we do. The motion that I put forward on behalf of the Australian Democrats should be supported. We need a multipartisan cross-party view on this. It should not be treated as a political football. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing can emphasise the state of panic the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has reached more than yesterday's statement that he had wiped out child poverty in Australia six months ahead of schedule. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset of the last election campaign, I committed a re-elected Labor government to an ambitious and proud goal: the elimination of child poverty in Australia.
Since re-election we have acted with determination to reach that goal-and we reached it ahead of target . . .

We are told that the Prime Minister then went on to say that the Government had also set basic levels. That was not said in his election speech. We did not hear anything about the basic parameters; it was a simple statement that he would eliminate child poverty by 1990. He has now told us that he has eliminated it ahead of schedule. The Prime Minister is a laughing stock not only among those who know the facts, that is, those working in the areas of poverty, but also among all those families living in poverty-the 360,000 supporting parents, the 239,500 living on pensions, all those single income families earning below $430 a week, the unemployed and the 224,000 breadwinners trying to feed their children.

The very day the survey was published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which pointed out that Australian householders were being forced to spend $506.87 a week on basic living costs while the average weekly wage was $501.10, the Prime Minister came out with this arrogant statement that he had wiped out child poverty in Australia. How do Government members feel? How ashamed and embarrassed the Ministers must be. I can hear them saying, `Crumbs, what is he on about now? What a galah!'. We had this on top of his arrogant statement that was reported in the paper where he said to an elderly pensioner, `You silly old bugger' just because the pensioner had told him that as Prime Minister he earned more in a week than most people earned in a year. The Prime Minister has become so arrogant. He is so far removed from the man in the street that he does not know what he is talking about. His credibility has been shot to pieces. For the good of Australia generally, he had better pull himself together and his Ministers ought to make sure that he does.

On Wednesday of last week, I explained to the Ministers that the mishandling of the pilots strike had already resulted in 80 stand-downs of casual workers in just one hotel in Hobart, plus thousands more in the tourist industry and other industries in our State. I pointed out that permanent workers in these hotels have been put on a four-day working week and have taken a cut of one-fifth of their salary. The very next day, in the middle of all these stand-downs, their leader made this incredible comment. Can honourable senators opposite understand the devastation of a supporting parent who has just been thrown out of a job when the Prime Minister says that everything is all right and their children are not in poverty? The survey points out-I think it is important that we look at it because Government members must understand-that five years ago a similar survey showed that Australians spent $361.84 on basic living costs. At that time the average gross household income was $453.60. A family was able to save about $91 a week. The same family today, this survey tells us, spends $506 and the average wage is $501.10. In other words, that family is down the drain $6 a week. This survey also points out that in New South Wales 44.5 per cent of a household's gross income is needed to service housing loans which is just about double the figure which the lending institutions have traditionally used as a benchmark for granting a loan.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) tells us that these crippling interest rates are needed because, after all, he made a bit of a mistake last year in estimating the growth in our country's consumption. That is great comfort to the single income families struggling to survive. Did the Prime Minister or his Ministers see the current affairs morning program on television yesterday just hours before the Prime Minister made his stupid statement? The program showed a father and mother explaining how they were trying to survive. The mother said:

We can't buy fresh fruit any more, that's a luxury in this house. Bread and butter seems to be our basic meal lately because meat is really a luxury. We try very hard to put meat on the table and we try very hard to put vegetables on the table. It just doesn't go that far all the time. So, we eat lots of bread and butter.

These two people were interviewed by the current affairs program reporter and, believe it or not, Australian Labor Party member Ross Free. The father and mother explained that seven families out of 25 families living in their street had had to move because they could not afford to stay there. Yet the Prime Minister has said, `No child is now living in poverty'. Perhaps Mr Free should talk to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister saying that homeless youth-the number of whom, according to the Burdekin report, is between 40,000 and 80,000-are children not living in poverty? I wish he would spend just one night walking around the streets of Kings Cross or St Kilda to find out the real poverty that those street children are facing. The age of these children is between eight years and 18 years.

It was just four months ago that a major television program Nobody's Children was shown. That program gave a slight indication of the poverty these children face. Does the Prime Minister claim that in such a short time as the four months lag he has eliminated poverty for those tens of thousands of street children? At that time, just on three months ago, I spoke about this issue in this place. I then asked whether the Prime Minister or his minders had bothered to view that program. At that time I asked, `If the Prime Minister saw that program, does he still maintain that he is on track for that wonderful election promise he made that by 1990 no one would be living in poverty?'. I said that the Prime Minister had abused and used those forgotten children for his own political purposes, giving them promises and expectations that at that time he knew he could never reach.

The Prime Minister has now proved beyond any shadow of doubt that these children are the forgotten children. He has been extolling the virtues of his social security policies and I give him full credit for those policies which have improved the incomes of those families most affected by the dreadful fall in living standards that has occurred under this Government over the last five years. The Prime Minister cannot ignore or forget the children at the bottom of the pile. It is not as if the Government is unaware of these children: there have been several reports on the subject. In 1980 the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare was asked to inquire into the problems of homeless youth including the appropriate responsibilities of governments. I was Chairman of that Committee. It reported to the Parliament in August 1982 and the Hawke Government came to power six months later. What has occurred since then? The number has gone up devastatingly-from an estimated 9,000 children on the streets then to between 40,000 and 80,000 this year. The Committee recognised:

. . . when family support breaks down irretrievably or is non-existent, both government and the community have a clear responsibility to provide the necessary support for the young person until such time as he or she is able to make the final transition to full independent living.
The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission brought down a report entitled Our Homeless Children that stated:

It is with deep concern that we present the report of our National Inquiry into Homeless Children and Young People. On behalf of the many thousands of children affected, we respectfully suggest that the Government give urgent consideration to the report and to the recommendations we have made.

Yet the Prime Minister still has done nothing. We gave the Government a profile of what homeless children were like. We said that they were probably between 15 and 18 years of age, Anglo-Saxon, had experienced conflict within the family, such as parental disputes, were unable to get along with de facto parents, et cetera. We gave a full run-down on children at risk. Yet the Prime Minister has said that they have all disappeared, that no child is now living in poverty. We visited each State and various shelters and took evidence from people working in the area. We met with people, including children. I am sure Senator Giles will remember the 14-year-old girl we met who said, `Mum's not too bad. She slips me $10 every now and then'. She had been forced to leave home because her de facto father had sexually abused her. We heard about a little boy and girl, seven and eight years old, who came home after school and found that the family had deserted them; no-one lived in the house any longer. They spent the night under the school until a teacher became aware of their problem. I remember very well the 15-year-old boy who was covered in tattoos and wearing a singlet. We visited the shelter where he was and over a cup of coffee I asked him, `What's your story, lad?'. He burst into tears and walked out of the room. The chap in charge of the shelter said; `He will toughen up. It is his first night away from home'.

I am well aware that the Government cannot wave a magic wand. I am well aware that it cannot legislate for good parents. But it has not picked up the basic recommendation of the Burdekin report which was:

Where children and young people leave or ought to leave home because of serious neglect or abuse, the Commonwealth should meet the obligation to support them, regardless of their age, in conditions where they are protected and can develop as required by the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

When I watched the television program Nobody's Children it brought back many memories of our Committee's inquiry. These children are not asking much. When we asked them, over a cup of coffee, how they thought their problems could be overcome they said, `Why don't you give us a block of flats? We could all live together in a block of flats'. When we said to them, `Do you really think that is practical?', a couple of the more sensible ones said, `No, we would only get into trouble. We know that if we did not have some sort of adult supervision we would get up to mischief and we would have the police in'. They do not ask for much. They just want something more stable and secure than the shelters they presently have where they can spend only a couple of weeks at a time before they have to move on. If the Prime Minister does not respond to the recommendations and acknowledge that there are tens of thousands of homeless youth, he does not deserve to be Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to pick up the last point that Senator Walters was making. I remind honourable senators that she was saying that, if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Government does not pick up the recommendations of the Burdekin report-the report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children-we are opening ourselves up to strong criticism. SPEECH.PARA: While I am on the question of homeless youth I would like to add two or three points to what Senator Walters was saying about the typical homeless young person. My recollections are from having served on the then Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare to which she referred. We were prepared to acknowledge then what Commissioner Burdekin has been acknowledging recently: there is no way of accurately assessing the number of young homeless people. We were able to say that approximately half of them would be away from their homes for only a relatively short time. They and their parents were probably looking for a breathing space in which to overcome whatever dispute had created that crisis. Senator Walters is absolutely right: we must be able to provide temporary shelter for these young people. Another quite substantial group of young people technically have no homes. They have been separated from their natural parents since very early life; they have had a history of institutionalisation; they have had a series of foster parents, et cetera. A great deal can be done to help these young people lead stable lives. In many cases we have been able to do that.

However, another characteristic is quite widespread among the homeless population-that is, a very strong mistrust of any type of authority. The last thing that these young people want is to be organised into any sort of regulated living. There is a real difficulty in working out how to help that group. Senator Walters will be glad to hear that over the last six years we have reached a state of affairs where we now have 1,390 crisis care accommodation units operating nationally. Many of these have been recently upgraded and many of them have only been established during the course of this Hawke Government. In the last financial year we opened 53 new services. We are assisting 80,000 people annually and, overall, there is a bed capacity of 14,000. Quite clearly, that is not sufficient. The capacity to deal with homeless people, whatever their age and whatever their condition, is not up to what is required, but it is considerably better than it was six years ago.

There has been a fair amount of confusion about what the Prime Minister said several years ago and what he said yesterday. At the risk of being repetitious, I will read exactly what he said yesterday to try to cast a little light on this debate. After all, this is an opportunity to get a few facts onto the record. The Prime Minister said:
At the outset of the last election campaign, I committed a re-elected Labor Government to an ambitious and proud goal: the elimination of child poverty in Australia.
We set ourselves historic benchmarks of support that would be available to low income families in Australia.
Since our re-election we have, as you understand perhaps better than most-
he was talking to the Australian Council of Social Service-
acted with determination to reach that goal.
In December 1987, we introduced the family allowance supplement as a first and substantial stage towards our benchmarks.
Since then, we have progressively increased family allowances and the family allowance supplement-most recently in the April statement this year.
As a result, the benchmarks we set ourselves were attained six months ahead of schedule.

I think most people understand now that the benchmarks have been established as a result of a very extensive inquiry by Dr Bettina Cass who suggested to the Government-this was accepted-that we should establish as a goal for each child in low income families an amount of 20 per cent of the married pension rate for children between the ages of 13 and 15 years and 15 per cent for children younger than that. We have reached that goal. Where is the criticism of those benchmarks? Who on the other side of Parliament has been prepared to analyse the benchmarks? If they honestly believe that those benchmarks are inadequate, why do they not say so and tell me what their benchmarks would be, how they would achieve them and why the benchmarks of the Government are not adequate? We do not hear criticism from those agencies that are informed about issues such as this. We certainly do not hear criticism about our benchmarks from the Brotherhood of St Laurence, which has been quoted time after time in this chamber. We do not hear criticisms from the Institute of Family Studies. It comments about the adequacy of our aims and goals as follows:

The centrepiece of the Government's strategy to assist low income families is the family allowance supplement (FAS). When FAS was introduced, in 1987, the Treasurer pledged that the rates of payment would be incomed to specific benchmarks related to the Prime Minister's commitment regarding child poverty. Those benchmarks were that combined weekly payments for children aged 12 and under would be set at 15 per cent of the married rate of pension and those for 13-15 year-olds would be set at 20 per cent of this rate.

As a result of the tax package, rates for younger children have been lifted to the benchmark via substantial increases in the rate of family allowance and those for 13-15 year-olds were raised, in addition to family allowance, by $3.10 per week to $34.10. By these means the Government's pledge to meet the benchmarks has been met. The new levels of FAS represent rises in real terms since 1983-84 of 41 per cent for younger children and 203 per cent for older children over the previous family income supplement payments.

I will give one example. A low income working family with two children aged 13 and eight years and renting privately could have been eligible before the family package for $12.80 a week in family payments. From 1 July this year this has increased to $96, tax free. This is the equivalent of something like $200 if it was a wage increase that was being taxed. This means that a considerable number of low income families in Australia, not only beneficiary families but those on low wages, are receiving cash in hand every month in their bank accounts. It is a considerably greater increase of money which, according to our benchmarks, should have raised these families out of financial embarrassment and inadequacy simply on account of there being dependant children. We have recognised that the dependency of children is the single greatest cause of poverty in Australia. These are the measures that we have taken to overcome that. I, like the Prime Minister, am justifiably proud of our record in this respect.

We are still waiting for some informed analysis or honest criticism from the Opposition. I, like the Australian Democrats, wish very much that we were able to achieve some sort of bipartisan approach to poverty. I do not, as some of my colleagues in the Opposition seem to, find that a matter for derision and mirth. We find the Democrats still referring to the Henderson poverty line. Apparently they have some difficulty with our new benchmarks. We do not know this for sure because they have not mentioned what those difficulties are. It was not very long ago-it was in 1986-that Senator Powell committed the Democrats to child payments of $22 a week indexed. That policy would lead to child payments today of about $28 a week. Yet Labor's policy has delivered since 1 July this year $33 a week for younger children and $43.10 a week for teenagers, indexed. I do not think the Democrats are able to retain any credibility until they develop a cohesive policy which is something different from saying that the Government has never done enough.

Having established what we believe to be adequate benchmarks, how are we meant to instruct, force or coerce families into using that money in the way in which some people seem to think it should be used? For example, the payments that we make, as a matter of principle, go to the carer, to the mother, until the child is 16 years of age. Then the choice can be made, if the child is entitled to Austudy, whether the money is to be paid to the 16-year-old or to the carer. In the event of that money being paid to the parents we, as a Government, say, `This at least is part of our responsibility fulfilled'. Are we somehow or other to dragoon the community into handing over that money to their children? What are the principles governing how people are to be influenced or how the Government is to interfere with the way in which that money is to be disbursed where young people are determined to be independent of their parents? We will do what we can to provide housing, advice, education, training and jobs for these young people. We have not been unsuccessful in that respect. But there is a degree to which people must be allowed to make their own decisions. There are many 14- and 15-year-olds who already believe that they are adult enough to do that.

We have to find ways-and once again I wish this were a bipartisan approach-to help them make the sorts of decisions that would enable them to have a healthy and wholesome lifestyle instead of dissipating their opportunities. It is a very difficult issue, and it is one that we should be working on together rather than having the sort of carping that we seem to be getting from the Democrats and the Opposition.

Our expenditure review process is well advanced and is cracking through options at an impressive pace. Some of our cuts will be politically unattractive-

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess there were not many children living in poverty who actually saw the heading in the Australian newspaper this morning which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Child poverty wiped out: PM.

It is lucky that they did not see it, because they would not have been amused. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday claimed at a social services conference that the Federal Government had wiped out child poverty and had done so six months ahead of schedule. That absolutely audacious comment is matched only by the original statement that he made in the 1987 election campaign-that by 1990 no Australian child would live in poverty. We know, of course, of the many qualifications since made to that.

Yesterday, to the surprise of the nation, the Prime Minister stood up and made this absolutely astonishing assertion. Nobody, I am sure, would have believed it, but it is necessary to debate this sort of behaviour and conduct lest anyone-that is, anyone who is not still living in poverty-be tempted to do so. Wherever there is a family who has trouble making its mortgage repayments, with a breadwinner without a job, there is a family with children who are living in poverty and who will continue to do so while that is the case. Bishop Hollingworth even made the comment that the Prime Minister was over-stretching his claim.

The basis of the matter that we are discussing today is the fact that we in this country have as a Prime Minister a man who would do such a thing-and do it to the children who are living in poverty in this country. The Minister who spoke for the Government, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus), and the last speaker who spoke for the Government side, Senator Giles, both went through the details of the steps the Government has taken to increase family allowances and various other benefits. None of us has suggested that those things have not been done. But my goodness, they are needed, are they not?

Just look at the economic situation in this country. Just think how tragic the situation would be if some of those benefits had not been brought in. Of course, we have not heard about how many people are actually benefiting from them. It is all very well to spray benefits all over the glossy magazines, but if the criteria for qualifying for benefits are so strict we are not helping many people at all. All of us here could spend the rest of the afternoon regaling listeners with stories and anecdotes of people who are suffering financially, who are living in poverty, whose children are living in poverty, who have tried to get help. I have referred people to social security offices, saying, `Isn't there anything you can do for this family?'. The response has been `No, there is not. They do not meet the criteria'. It is all very well to spend millions of dollars promoting elaborate schemes and making announcements about what is available, but if people are not going to qualify it is of little use.

We are not saying that nothing has been done. I invite Senator Giles, though, to re-check her arithmetic. She referred to an increase amounting to some $90, I think, and then attempted to translate that into the figure it would be if it were a salary increase minus the taxation. I am sure that she was not exaggerating but I have a feeling that she got her figures somewhat wrong when she was doing that. I do not know whether he really meant it in 1987 or whether it was a throw away line, a throw away promise-we know about his throw away promises, they come and go pretty quickly-but he really does have a history of making quite outrageous promises, the reality of which is not met. These things are going to continue-low inflation, lower than the world average, growth above the world average, interest rates coming down . . .

It's obvious that at some stage this year they will fall.

That was said in January 1989. They have not fallen. Ask anyone who has a mortgage what has been happening to them. The Prime Minister perhaps does not know, although yesterday he did a rather cute deal with the banks, not so that interest rates would fall, but so that they would be prevented from rising. It really has not been of much benefit to anyone. He must have been campaigning again in Tasmania. Earlier in his career as Prime Minister he stated:
We will certainly go for the full three years.

We have heard that often enough. It looks as though we just might go for the full term this time, but not if the Prime Minister can avoid it. Yesterday's little deal with the banks tends to make one think that December this year is a pretty odds-on favourite for an election. The outrageous claims that I have referred to go on. The Prime Minister makes the outrageous claim that he does not make outrageous claims. He stated:

All politicians like to be the bearers of good news, and I claim no exception for myself on that score. But I have been very careful not to make any claims about which I cannot be absolutely certain . . . I will have no part of needless exaggeration.

Poor fellow! He has either one problem or another. In the election campaign of 1987 he made the cruellest, most reckless and most outrageous claim and exaggeration that he has ever made. He stated that by 1990 no Australian child would live in poverty. As we all know, he has attempted to modify that statement since that time. Today we heard about benchmarks and all sorts of things. Senator Button's answer to my question will make interesting reading when the Hansard is finally produced. On 1 July 1987 he stated:
There will be no watering down of the pledge that was made.

That in itself was another broken undertaking. On The World Today in 1987, in answer to the question, `Will children be lifted above the Henderson poverty line?' he said, `That is right'. That was subsequently qualified. I think the community is rightly quite sceptical about these sorts of claims and the statements that he makes. We recognise that there are difficulties. I do not believe in our sort of society that we would ever live without somebody being in poverty; that is the nature of things. We could all think of the circumstances in which it happens, no matter how much is done. The brazen callousness of making such a promise and attempting to make people believe that that is what can be achieved is what we are talking about. We are letting him know that poverty continues. Julian Disney, the President of the Australian Council of Social Service, said in October last year:

There is no prospect of the Government achieving its child poverty promise however diluted by redefinition that promise may be, unless it devotes substantially greater resources to the task than has been promised . . . Some apparent increases in assistance will do little if any more than compensate for inflation . . .

Those working with low income families every day know what an enormous problem poverty is and the way that it affects children. The Prime Minister either has an inability to comprehend it, or is out of touch with the reality of life. He has talked about the definition of poverty. The Burdekin report has been referred to and some of the definitions in that relate to the issues that we all know are relevant when we discuss poverty. Chapter 4 of the report refers to the rights of the child. It states that a child should enjoy the benefits of social security, and suggests how that might be done. It also says the child should have the right to adequate nutrition, housing, recreation and medical services as part of the declaration of the rights of the child. It states that those things should be adequate by a standard relevant to the country being discussed. It states:

There must be some standard against which a sufficient livelihood should be measured. A street dweller in Bombay is alive and manages to exist from day to day . . . Is this to be the standard of a sufficient livelihood in contemporary Australia? Clearly not.

It goes on, but I have not got time to read as much of it as I would like to. We require a standard of living in this country which we know ought to be available to all children, and not a mere subsistence. If the Prime Minister is suggesting that children are merely living above the subsistence level, that is not good enough. The Macquarie Dictionary definition of `poverty' is as follows:
the condition of being poor with respect to money, goods, or means of subsistence . . . deficiency or lack of something specified.

We have heard about homelessness, single parent families and families where nobody has employment, and it is the children who suffer in those situations. That suffering is not restricted to one child. Mr Burdekin suggests that there are 25,000 homeless children and 150,000 children living in poverty. Nobody can be absolutely precise about a figure, but there is no doubt such suffering exists. If the Prime Minister has any doubts, I can assure him that there are still families living in poverty and doing so here in Canberra.

I contacted a number of organisations this morning, as I frequently do, to talk about the existing situation in Canberra. I am not surprised to find that the services of each of those organisations are stretched. The Salvation Army is now seeing more low income families who are above the cut-off for family assistance, who have mortgages and medical expenses and who can no longer survive on what used to be regarded as a reasonable wage. Those organisations express concern that we are producing a generation of children who accept almost Third World living standards with no hope for a better future. The Salvation Army in Canberra saw 620 clients a month last year and is now seeing 870 a month. The St Vincent de Paul Society reports a similar trend. To the end of June, St Vincent de Paul saw 28,552 persons and assisted them with cash and goods. That is in a population of 260,000.

It is not only people on social security who are looking for help and benefits. I can give an example of a man with an income of $35,000, with a dependent wife and four children. The mere mention of $35,000 might sound like a great deal of money but, after paying for mortgage instalments, food and clothing, that is about it. That family is not able to provide any extras. The Prime Minister will say they are not living in poverty because they have a house and they have food and clothing. What standard does he find acceptable in this country? That is the challenge we offer him. At what level does he say a child is living in poverty? I do not believe that his definition of the word is the same as mine. I do not believe his is satisfactory. There are 50 to 60 children in Canberra who are homeless and living out and about on any night one cares to go around this city. They are certainly living in poverty. The Prime Minister has done absolutely nothing to produce evidence to substantiate his claim that there is no child living in poverty and that he is six months ahead of his schedule. That is perhaps the most astonishing thing of all. There is absolutely not a shred of evidence to support the statement that he has made.

The Government's priorities are funny. An enormous amount of money has been spent promoting Priority One, Skillshare and Jobstart. I could go on and on with the resources that have been put into promotion of schemes, but how many of them have turned into jobs for the young people who have not got jobs and who cannot get them? The last Budget provides $2 a week extra for pensioners, from next April. What are the airlines being paid at the present time? It is approximately $10m a week to cover their costs and we are in the seventh week of the strike. The other day $60m was found for Eastman Kodak Co. Over $3m was found for extra stamps because the Labor Party wanted to increase the stamp allowance for members in the House of Representatives so that they could get on with their campaigning. The priorities of this Government are all wrong. I suggest that it does not understand what people are suffering. I certainly challenge the way that it is able to take from taxpayers to spend on just some of the items that I have previously referred to when so many are still living in poverty and will continue to do so. The Prime Minister should be condemned for being so callous as to suggest that he has met that promise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very sad occasion because 1 hour 45 minutes of the Senate's time that could have been used constructively has been wasted by people who did not bother to check whether a quote in the Australian that they would have liked to have been true was true. It has been said several times-and established by both Senator Bolkus and Senator Giles-that the headline in the Australian is not true. In case anybody was listening to the last part of the debate and heard Senator Reid repeat the false allegation, I will repeat what the Prime Minister said yesterday. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset of the last election campaign, I committed a re-elected Labor Government to an ambitious and proud goal: the elimination of child poverty in Australia.
We made it clear that our pledge in this matter was to do what it was in our power to do-that is, to create the situation where there was no financial need for a child to live in poverty.
To meet that goal, we set ourselves, in consultation with the welfare community, historic benchmarks of support that would be available to low income families in Australia.
Since our re-election we have acted with determination to reach that goal-and we reached it ahead of target.

That is what was said. Goals that were set explicitly and simultaneously with that statement on the very same day in the very same document have been achieved exactly in the terms that were set out yesterday. The Australian got it wrong. It is entitled to do that, I guess; it is a free country. But the Opposition should not waste our time and consciously misuse the Senate to perpetuate that error. In effect, the Government is being condemned because all it has achieved is the greatest program of assistance for young Australians and for Australian families with children ever developed. We are giving more effective assistance than has been provided on any previous occasion.

The Prime Minister in 1987 for the first time explicitly outlined targets, chapter and verse. The Opposition, on the other hand, throws around generalisations and makes frightening threats about cuts that might be forthcoming. The Prime Minister outlined the targets, chapter and verse, and gave exact percentages. They have been achieved. We set the benchmarks against which we could be tested and we have achieved them. The benchmark of a pension set at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings was set and has been achieved. The benchmarks for family support for families with children were set and have been achieved. Nobody pretends there is nothing more to be done, but they are substantial achievements.

Senator Giles and Senator Bolkus mentioned the substantial support for this style of approach and for the achievements given by the Institute of Family Studies, from Bishop Hollingworth, and from others. Also for the first time these support payments have been indexed, thus protecting them for the first time against inflation. Those payments were introduced in 1976 and in the period of the previous coalition Government were increased only once in seven years. When taken in conjunction with the increase in Austudy payments for children at school, the increased school retention rates, for which explicit targets have also been set, the homeless youth package, and the child support package, we have a comprehensive program of reform for Australian families with children that will lift and has lifted many families out of poverty.

The best way to lift families out of poverty is to give people jobs because unemployment is the greatest cause of poverty. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), sneers at the Government's job creation achievement of 1.5 million jobs. He says anybody could do that if they were prepared to create enough debt, which is a clear example of his priorities and an ominous warning. In his Thatcherite way and in Thatcherite language he is giving a warning to the people of Australia as to what might happen should the fate of a change in government befall them. We should be congratulating the Government on the most substantial package of measures for families with children and we should welcome its courage in setting explicit targets and the discipline to reach them. There are still problems; a lot remains to be done. But the Senate will serve the nation much more constructively by indulging in a calm, sober, rational discussion of the problems and the relative merits of alternative solutions, none of which have appeared today, rather than making a superficial, smart-alec attempt to score cheap points by misrepresenting serious contributions to the national debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to set the record straight on a statement I made in Question Time today which inadvertently misrepresented the position of the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Charles Blunt. In Question Time today I referred to a joint appeal for clemency for a South African man, Mangena Jeffrey Boesman, due to be hanged in South Africa today which was endorsed late yesterday by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines).

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of my answer I said that I understood that the Leader of the National Party, Mr Blunt, had declined to sign the appeal. I expressed my regret that he had chosen to take that course. I have since been contacted by Mr Blunt and told by him that he had not declined to sign the letter, that he had been out of contact with his office during the relevant period, and that if he had known about the appeal he would have agreed to sign. I, of course, accept Mr Blunt's word and I am happy to correct the record. I apologise to him publicly, as I have privately, for the misrepresentation of his position. That misrepresentation came about as a result of an unfortunate misunderstanding that occurred in the course of a complicated chain of communications between Mr Blunt's office, Mr Peacock's office, the Prime Minister's office and my office in which a message from a staffer that he could not commit Mr Blunt to that statement was eventually retailed to me as a message that `Mr Blunt would not go along' with the statement. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of the statement in question to which I am very glad to say Mr Blunt has now attached his support.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
JOINT APPEAL TO THE STATE PRESIDENT OF SOUTH AFRICA
Mr State President

We, the undersigned, call on you most urgently, and in the name of human compassion, to grant clemency to Mr Mangena Jeffrey Boesman who is, we understand, sentenced to be executed on Friday 29 September.

We are strongly and universally opposed to imposition of the death penalty, which is an inhumane and degrading form of punishment in violation of the most fundamental of human rights-the right to life. It is because of this that capital punishment has been abolished Federally and in all Australian States, and that the Australian Government regularly raises its concern over the death penalty with other governments.
Moreover, in the case of Mangena Jeffrey Boesman we are deeply concerned that his execution would constitute a particularly severe injustice.

We note that the case was originally heard by a single judge and leave to appeal was refused. We understand that Mr Boesman and his fellow accused were also severely disadvantaged at the start of their trial in November 1986 by their lack of adequate legal representation, that State witnesses were drawn from among those present in the crowd and that such evidence might well therefore be tainted by fear of themselves being charged.
You were able to commute the death sentences of two of his co-accused, and we urge you to do the same in the case of Mr Boesman.

If Mr Boesman is executed, it will be seen by the world as the first political execution authorised by your new Government. It will also be a major blow to the prospects for peace and justice in South Africa.

We have noted that in your inauguration statement you pledged yourself to a quest for peace in South Africa through fairness and justice. We consider that it would signal most clearly to the world that you are determined to pursue this quest if you are able to grant clemency in this case. We call on you most urgently to do so.
Bob Hawke
Prime Minister of Australia
Andrew Peacock
Leader of the Opposition
Janine Haines,
Leader Australian Democrats
28 September 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring before the Senate the plight of the Queensland pineapple industry which is fighting to protect its market from imports of canned pineapples from very low cost countries. There is no industry more synonymous with Queensland than the Queensland pineapple industry and there is no brand more identifiable with it than the Golden Circle brand. Every household in Australia would have tasted and enjoyed Golden Circle products such as tinned pineapple, fruit salad, beetroot, peas, cordial and the Estral 100 per cent fruit juice tetra pack. Whatever product Golden Circle markets, the housewife-or the householder-can be confident that she is providing her family with the best product that money can buy, prepared under hygienic conditions and under State and Federal government health supervision. The best Queensland grown ingredients guarantee a product that is second to none. The Golden Circle cannery is owned and operated by Queensland fruit and vegetable growers. It is a cooperative providing 1,700 jobs in the cannery at full production. It also provides a market for 1,000 fruit and vegetable growers, 550 of whom are pineapple growers. The Golden Circle cannery in Brisbane is the only canner of pineapple products in Australia and is acknowledged by experts as one of the most efficient fruit and vegetable processors in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is against this background that the Australian pineapple industry faces its biggest challenge-to hold its market share against cheap imports. To hold market share the growers have made every effort to make their production more effective and efficient and their farming methods more cost effective. But there is a limit to which farmers can go in cost cutting before growers start to go out the door backwards. That point has just about been reached. Pineapple growers are now asking what will happen in two or three years time. I make this speech in the Senate because there does not seem to be great understanding of this problem at a government level. I asked a question in the Senate on 31 August seeking help for the industry and was given an answer by Senator Button. He said that he would not support Mr Keith Wright's call for a 10,000-tonne quota and penalty tariffs for anything above that. In a supplementary question I asked Senator Button whether, as an interim measure, he would be prepared to reinstate the 10 per cent Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) tariff on canned pineapples that his Government effectively reduced to 5 per cent. His answer was an unequivocal no.

On 5 September Senator Button gave the Senate a more detailed answer that clearly indicated that he and his advisers do not have a good understanding of the problem. The nub of Senator Button's answer was that imports are at a level of only 13 per cent and that it is all Golden Circle's fault anyway because it refused to process a generic or home brand for G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd. Senator Button implied that Coles was then forced into importing pineapples from low cost countries and that the reduction of the IAC tariff by his Government from 10 per cent to 5 per cent had not increased imports.

Therefore, I feel I must now set down the true position of the pineapple industry in Queensland for the Government and Senator Button to understand. Since 1985 Golden Circle has realised that its industry was threatened by imports. It was not prepared to sit idly by and watch its market share erode and its position as Australia's No. 1 supplier go down without a fight. The Golden Circle cannery engaged in a vigorous and expensive advertising campaign promoting its products by offering recipes in family magazines and by expanding export sales, mainly to New Zealand. This campaign has lifted domestic sales of canned pineapple from 108,148 tonnes in 1985 to 123,400 tonnes in 1988-an increase of 15,252 tonnes or, in percentage terms, 14.1 per cent. Golden Circle should be congratulated for achieving this increase in sales figures for its canned pineapple sales.

It is ironic that by creating a demand for canned pineapples, Golden Circle has in fact lifted the sales of the imported generic brand product marketed by the huge multinational grocery chains, which have not spent a cent on promoting canned pineapple but have piggybacked on Golden Circle's promotional campaigns. While the consumption of tinned pineapple has risen by 15,252 tonnes, or 14.1 per cent, due to Golden Circle's aggressive marketing, imports have risen from 12,637 tonnes in 1985-or 11 per cent of market share-to 26,000 tonnes in 1988. This is an increase of 21 per cent.

I will now put it in simple terms for Mr Kerin, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy; Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce; and Senator Cook, the Minister representing Mr Kerin in the Senate, whom I have lobbied on this matter and who have agreed to examine this contribution. Sales of canned pineapples have increased by 14.1 per cent. Imports have increased by 21 per cent. Senator Button had that figure of 13 per cent totally wrong. The Australian market share has decreased by 8 per cent. This figure is rising as rapidly as 2 per cent every two months.

The fact is that, no matter how effective an advertising campaign is or how much promotion a company does, there is a limit on the growth of that market. That 14 per cent increase in five years-not in price but in actual pineapples consumed-is extracting as much out of the market as is possible. From 1985 to 1989 imports have continued to grow from 11 per cent to 21 per cent. If this trend continues it will be entirely at the expense of the Australian grown products as there is little or no further growth in the Australian market. I add that, while the industry has been under attack from cheap imports, it has aggressively lifted its export sales from 10,115 tonnes in 1985 to about 18,000 tonnes in 1988. This export market is also under pressure from the pineapple exports of lower cost, from the South East Asian countries.

Let it be clearly stated that the growers and Golden Circle cannery have not sat on their hands and done nothing over the past five years. They have done everything possible commercially to protect their industry. The costs have been heavy, apart from the expensive advertising campaigns promoting the consumption of canned pineapples. The growers have not had a price rise since 1985-five years without receiving even a 1c increase. In fact the price of No. 2 pool has fallen from $240 per tonne in 1985 to $165 per tonne in 1989, while the No. 1 pool has been static at $240 a tonne for five years. In 1985 a total intake of 105,226 tonnes gave growers a grand total payment of $25,734,240. If the consumer price index applied to this income over the next three years, the income should have been $38,864,648. It is calculated by the industry that income was down to $29,526,345-a decrease in real terms of 11 per cent. The growers know that any increase in price will amount to a further erosion of their market share. They have had to tighten their belts another notch every year for five years. Prices have been held firm on the retailers' shelves for 18 months.

Another economy the industry has been prepared to make is to process pineapples of only a certain size which have a recovery rate above 20 per cent. The result of that particular decision is that 12,000 tonnes of good pineapples are going to rot in the field because it is more expensive to process them. After all of these economic concessions by the pineapple industry, it is no wonder that I was provoked into calling Senator Button's answer unreasonable. Senator Button's background is legal and he obviously does not understand marketing. I found his response to my question surprising when he said that Golden Circle had rejected a request by G. J. Coles and Co. Ltd to package pineapples under Coles' Farmland label. Senator Button said:

Golden Circle insisted that it could only market products under its own brand labels. Coles and other supermarket chains subsequently placed orders with overseas suppliers who were prepared to meet their requirements and this has contributed to the increase in imports.
To say the least, those remarks of Senator Button were insensitive and would offend the growers and the 1,700 workers who produce and process Australia's pineapple crops.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he correct?

—No, I will come to that. Home labels or, as they are known, generic brands, are generally considered to be inferior, second-rate products processed with inferior second-quality ingredients. It could be said that home brands are made to a price and not to quality or a recipe. I do not believe that Golden Circle would be prepared to put its name on a product that was not the best available and to sell that product to the Australian people. It would be impossible to manufacture a home or generic brand product in Australia without cutting prices or lowering the quality of the product in the can. Certainly, it would not be a very clever commercial decision for a grower-owned cannery to subsidise a generic brand so that this brand could compete with its own quality product.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that even if Golden Circle offered a generic brand at 20 per cent cheaper, it still could not compete with the cheaper imported products which can be landed at 64c a litre in Australia; so much for Senator Button's explanation that Golden Circle's refusal to provide a generic brand has increased imports. The Government must realise that grocery chains do not want to buy dearer, higher quality local products and market them under their own brand names when they can bring into Australia cheaper products, sell them under their own generic labels, and enjoy huge mark-ups that give the chains maximum profits. That is the bottom line: maximum profits.

I fully recognise and appreciate that reduction of trade barriers will give greater access to Australian commodities. We are facing a difficult problem that must be addressed if we are to sustain a canned pineapple industry. We must allow our growers a fair chance to survive and to play on an even field. The Government must examine whether an anti-dumping case can be sustained on canned pineapple. The normal criterion upon which to establish anti-dumping is to prove that tinned pineapple is sold in the country of process at a higher price than in the country to which it is exported. In the case of imported canned pineapple from South East Asia this is impossible to prove simply because the country of origin does not allow retail sales of canned pineapple in that country. In fact, the Dole Pineapple Co. of Thailand and the Great Pineapple Co. of Indonesia proudly advise that 100 per cent export of their production is part of the established agreement with the host government. Therefore, it is impossible to establish whether there is a profit component in the imported pineapple at all.

The anti-dumping authority must also assess what assistance host governments give pineapple processors by way of tax holidays, subsidised loans, subsidised freight, cheap land leases and subsidised fertilisers. All of these represent help that is given by host governments. These cost savings must all be included in the price of a tin of pineapple to establish the true cost of manufacture. If the price is less in the country of import than the true cost of manufacture there is a case for anti-dumping to be sustained.

There is also evidence to suggest that some Third World countries are using pineapple exports as a means of obtaining hard currency rather than as a genuine business with a profit motivation. I say this because some countries have entered into long term contracts with suppliers, then undercut those prices on the spot market, suggesting that dumping is taking place. I say to the Senate that it is not only the pineapple industry that is under attack from cheap imports but many other food items are also brought into Australia and marketed under generic labels. Many grocery products are brought in and are packed under generic labels for Coles, Woolworths and Franklins. These products are discreetly labelled with the country of origin in type sometimes as small as 1.5 millimetres-slightly bigger than a pin head. Ironically, the housewife is prepared to trust these imported food products because she identifies the home brand with a major retail store and associates the product with the store rather than with the country of origin.

It is time that the Government and its instrumentalities recognised the problem faced by our rural producers and provided for at least a fair go for our horticultural industries. Australian horticulture is competing with countries that have wage structures as low as $1.50 a day, hygiene standards less than those which are required in Australia, and products grown with fertiliser and insecticides that would not meet Australian health or environmental standards. Let it be a requirement that the country of origin be marked in a prominent position on the can in lettering the same size as those denoting the product for sale. The Industries Assistance Commission has brought down interim recommendations on packaging, and nominating the country of origin in respectable minimum sized writing was not one of those recommendations. Let us hope that the final recommendations to be released in December will pick up this important requirement.

I have had private discussion with Senator Bolkus on this matter and I believe that he is aware of the problem. The housewife who shops for her family deserves to know what she is buying and under what conditions that product is processed. She can make a value judgment as to whether it is in the best interests of her family to buy a cheaper, inferior product or go for the first grade Australian grown and produced item.

There is an urgent need to examine the pineapple industry and the full 10 per cent tariff recommended by the IAC, which was magnanimously removed by the Government in July 1986, for developing countries. The pineapple industry does not mind the Government being magnanimous and helping developing countries but not so that the burden is left entirely on the shoulders of the 550 pineapple growers and 1,700 workers. If the Government makes those decisions, let the whole of Australia carry them-not just a tiny industry.

While it can be recognised that South East Asian countries that grow pineapples are developing, the canning companies that are operating in those countries are hardly developing. They are huge, American-owned and controlled and between the two of them-Dole and Del Monte-they control 43 per cent of the world canned pineapple market. Their mode of operation is to identify a country with cheap labour and subsidised land, bring in their technology and machinery and flood the market.

The 5 per cent tariff the Government removed from the industry has gone on subsidising an American public company with its shareholders in America and profits repatriated to its United States shareholders. That is certainly not giving the Australian industry a fair go, but no doubt the American shareholders of the Dole and Del Monte canneries would say a big thank you to the Australian Government every time they receive a dividend cheque.

Tests in the United States of America have shown that some Thailand and South East Asian companies add citric acid to lower the brix-acid ratio. With low levels of citric acid two problems occur-taste and sterility. Most canners in Thailand are adding citric acid to pineapple products, but not all declare it on their labels. This high natural acid : sugar ratio occurs naturally in Queensland grown pineapple and is deficient in the imported product. The overseas cannery must add a chemical to artificially improve the quality of the imported canned fruit. The low levels of natural acid affect the taste of pineapple juice, so much so that in Europe distributors are forced to mix good Golden Circle juice with South East Asian juice to improve the quality of their product. Also, low levels of acid as found in imported canned pineapple can allow pathogens, which are micro-organisms, to survive the cooking process.

I make this contribution because the Government and the Ministers responsible must understand what is happening to this $183m industry. There is an urgent need to see that Australia's horticultural industries are not competing against dumped products, and to recognise that clearly marked labelling would help maintain the market share of imported pineapple. I have presented this contribution so that the Government can fully understand the crisis facing the pineapple industry. I ask it to give its immediate attention to the problems of the growers and the process workers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 28 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did Senator Richardson, when acting for the Minister during his absence on 16 June 1988, in his considered prepared response to my Question without Notice `Will the Minister be renewing the Imam's visa' (Imam Al Hilaly of the Lakemba Mosque) say that the Imam's application for permanent residence would be considered by the Minister on his return from overseas, when in fact the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs also had before it an application for a temporary extension of the Imam's visa to cover a visit to the Middle East planned for only 11 days after Senator Richardson's reply.

(2) As this further extraordinary extension of the Imam's already extended visa (a benefit not available to other temporary visitors) expired last week (week ended 19 August 1989), what is his present status and when does the Minister plan to determine this matter of a man who, despite undertakings to the contrary, has repeatedly breached the bipartisan multicultural guidelines by inflammatory, discriminatory and grossly offensive activity aimed at disturbing the cohesion of the Australian community.
(3) Why did Senator Richardson apparently mislead the Senate on the status of Imam Al Hilaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 15 June 1989, Senator Michael Baume asked a question about the Imam Hilaly's visa. Clearly, the Senator was asking not about visas-which authorise a carrier to bring a person to Australia-but about the Imam's entry permit.
On 16 June 1989, Senator Richardson correctly noted that the Imam had applied on 4 May 1989 for a further entry permit and correctly outlined the processes for its consideration.

Coincidentally, the Imam applied on 15 June 1989 for a return visa, that is a visa which would allow a carrier to bring him to Australia should he leave Australia. The Imam's visa application also entailed a consideration of the type of entry permit which might be accorded to him when, as he wished, he returned to the border after his brief overseas visit for religious purposes.

This application was only received by the State Director of my Department on 16 June 1989 and this application was of little consequence to the substantive issue of the Imam's application for permanent residence, or indeed, possible consideration of extended temporary residence.

(2) As noted above, Senator Baume's questions confuse visas with entry permits. An entry permit to Imam Hilaly was due to expire on 30 June 1989 and a further temporary entry permit-to accommodate his overseas visit and return to Australia-expired on 19 August 1989. The provision of re-entry visas and further temporary entry permits to temporary residents is not extraordinary. The policy guiding the Department clearly contemplates such issues-even to temporary residents who have applied for permanent residence.
(3) Senator Richardson did not mislead the Senate on the status of Imam Hilaly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 31 August 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Australian police does Australia have in a peacekeeping role in Cyprus.
(2) What percentage of the total peacekeeping force in Cyprus do they represent.
(3) How is their duty defined.
(4) What salary and conditions of service do they receive from the Australian Government.
(5) Do they receive financial assistance from any other source; if so, what sources and what financial assistance.
(6) Have any deaths or injuries occurred or been sustained by any member of the Australian contingent.
(7) How often are they rotated.
(8) What ranks are the police involved.
(9) Do they require any extra or special training before deployment to Cyprus.
(10) Do they carry arms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At present there are 20 members of the Australian Police Contingent in Cyprus, drawn from the ranks of the Australian Federal Police (AFP).

(2) The United Nations Civilian Police (UNCIVPOL) consists of 20 Australian and 15 Swedish Police. The total United Nations Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) has 2,000 members. Australian police make up 1 per cent of this total.

(3) UNCIVPOL is responsible for all reported or detected incidents involving civilians or their property in the United Nations Buffer Zone (UNBZ). It provides an independent and neutral liaison point between the Cypriot Police and the Turkish Cypriot Police Element in matters which cross community boundaries.

UNCIVPOL is tasked by HQ, UNFICYP to assist the UN Humanitarian Branch by escorting Greek and Turkish civilians across the UNBZ. It also aids in locating, interviewing and providing aid to Turkish or Greek Cypriots living in the opposite community. UNCIVPOL is also tasked to provide police support to other UNFICYP units in emergencies.

(4) Salary and terms and conditions of Australian members of UNCIVPOL are generally the same as for other members of the AFP. Provisions relating to service in Cyprus are included in Determination No. M31 under section 30 of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. This determination covers such considerations as term of posting, hours of duty, removal expenses, travelling allowance, storage of furniture and effects, insurance, public holidays and uniform issue.

(6) In the 25 years since the first Australian contingent arrived, there have been three deaths, two due to traffic accidents and one caused by a land mine. Injuries have been traffic injuries, or of a minor domestic nature.

(7) and (8) The Australian contingent consists of one Commander, 3 Superintendents and 16 Sergeants. Eleven of the contingent are Constables holding the brevet rank of Sergeant. Officers are rotated every twelve months. Sergeants are rotated every six months, with an option of a further six-month tour.
(9) Members receive a one-week briefing on their duties and responsibilities before departure, and one week of four-wheel drive vehicle training.

(10) No. At first UNCIVPOL insisted that all members should be armed on duty, but since the first tour in 1964, this is no longer the case. No Australian policeman has been confronted with a situation requiring the use of personal arms and it is generally felt that the presence of unarmed police relaxes tension in the UN Buffer Zone.
